trips_llama3.polished_text: Molecular science encompasses a broad spectrum of fields that study the structures, properties, and interactions of molecules, including various disciplines such as chemistry, physics, biology, and computer science. Molecular science is pivotal in drug discovery applications, including target identification and validation, structure-based drug design, and side effect prediction. However, most existing methods of discovering new molecules or tweaking existing ones are time-consuming, expensive, and prone to failure (Rodrigues et al., 2016). In recent years, computational methods have shown significant advantages in molecule generation and modification (Bilodeau et al., 2022). These techniques enable rapid identification and optimization of potential drug candidates; however, they are limited by their computational demands. Fortunately, artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning technologies have emerged as powerful tools for molecular science, revolutionizing the field and its applications. These technologies have the potential to revolutionize the field, improving speed, accuracy, and scalability in molecular discovery and understanding. Large Language Models (LLMs) have made significant contributions to both Natural Language Processing (NLP) and molecular science, with notable applications in the latter. MolT5 (Edwards et al., 2022), a variant of the T5 model (Raffel et al., 2020), offers capabilities in molecule captioning (Mol2Cap) and text-based molecule generation (Cap2Mol). LLMs, such as MolT5, can describe molecules in words and generate structures from text. However, text-to-text models using these models still struggle to integrate molecular structure data and understand molecular images. To fuse and understand multi-modal data, multi-modal large language models (MLLMs), such as CLIP (Radford et al., 2021), ALIGN (Jia et al., 2021), and BEIT-3 (Wang et al., 2022c), have established a foundation for adaptive learning across image-text modalities. In the context of molecular science, SwinOCSR (Xu et al., 2022) has been designed for image recognition, and it has shown significant benefits in document comprehension and multi-modal drug discovery database construction (Wang et al., 2022b), enhancing the field's capabilities. MoleculeSTM (Liu et al., 2022) and MoMu (Su et al., 2022) integrate the Simplified Molecular Input Line Entry System (SMILES) (Weininger, 1988) with graph representations to facilitate molecular property prediction tasks. This limitation underscores the need for modality data alignment processes, where multi-modal models can outperform language models by integrating diverse data types to enhance feature representation. The effectiveness of our multi-modal model is demonstrated through extensive ablation studies, which showed an improvement of 10%-15% over single-modality models. In the subsequent sections, Section 3 provides an overview of our model's principles. Sections 5, 6, and 7 discuss the features, limitations, and conclusions of our model in detail.

llama3.polished_text:
Molecular science encompasses a broad spectrum of fields that focus on the intricate structures, properties, and interactions of molecules. This interdisciplinary field draws upon the principles of chemistry, physics, biology, and computer science to understand and manipulate molecular behavior. Molecular science is instrumental in drug discovery applications, such as target identification and validation, structure-based drug design, and predicting side effects. However, most existing methods of discovering new molecules or modifying existing ones can be time-consuming, expensive, and prone to failure (Rodrigues et al., 2016). More recently, computational methods have demonstrated significant advantages in molecule generation and tweaking (Bilodeau et al., 2022), enabling rapid identification and optimization of potential drug candidates. However, these computational methods are limited by substantial computational demands.

Fortunately, artificial intelligence (AI) and deep learning have emerged as powerful tools for molecular science. These technologies have the potential to revolutionize the field by improving speed, accuracy, and scalability in molecular discovery and understanding. Large Language Models (LLMs) have made significant progress in Natural Language Processing (NLP) and molecular science. MolT5 (Edwards et al., 2022), based on the T5 (Raffel et al., 2020), includes capabilities such as molecule captioning (Mol2Cap) and text-based molecule generation (Cap2Mol). LLMs like MolT5 help describe molecules in words and generate structures from text. However, these text-to-text models cannot fully utilize the advantages of molecular structure data and understand molecular images.

To fuse and understand multi-modal data, the multi-modal large language models (MLLMs) like CLIP (Radford et al., 2021), ALIGN (Jia et al., 2021), and BEIT-3 (Wang et al., 2022c) have laid the groundwork for adaptive learning across image-text modalities. In molecular science, SwinOCSR (Xu et al., 2022) is designed for image recognition, which significantly aids in document comprehension and multi-modal drug discovery database construction (Wang et al., 2022b). In addition, MoleculeSTM (Liu et al., 2022) and MoMu (Su et al., 2022) can combine the Simplified Molecular Input Line Entry System (SMILES) (Weininger, 1988) and graph representations for molecular property prediction tasks.

Existing language models excel in processing textual molecular data, but processing molecular graphs and images is difficult, typically relying on processed vector encodings. This limitation highlights the need for a modality data alignment process, where multi-modal models outperform language models by integrating diverse data types for enhanced feature representation. Moreover, the scalability of molecular representation and generation models remains a significant challenge. Models capable of effectively fusing three or more modalities are scarce, and the complexity of integrating these diverse modalities, often with missing or incomplete data, calls for advanced modeling techniques.

To address the significant scalability challenges in molecular science and to harness the potential of vast quantities of unlabeled multi-modal data, we have developed a robust neural network architecture, which we refer to as GIT-Mol. At the core of GIT-Mol is the GIT-Former, which incorporates an advanced cross-attention mechanism. It is capable of mapping data from various modalities into a unified multi-modal representation. This approach not only enhances the model's ability to process and integrate diverse modalities efficiently but also effectively bridges the scalability gap, providing a powerful tool for various molecular applications.

Our main contributions are as follows: 

• To utilize the available large amount of unlabeled multi-modal data, we develop a specialized multimodal large language model, GIT-Mol (700M), to efficiently cover all three modalities in molecular science (graph, image, and text) for molecule generation, molecule captioning, molecular image recognition, and molecular property prediction.

• We present GIT-Former, a novel modality mixer designed with a cross-attention mechanism, enabling seamless fusion of three molecular modalities. Each fusion strategy within GIT-Former operates at the molecule level, ensuring optimal flexibility and scalability. The effectiveness of our multi-modal model is demonstrated in our extensive ablation studies, which provides an improvement of 10%-15% over the single-modality models.

We present a comprehensive overview of GIT-Mol in Figure 1. The architecture is composed of four primary components: Internal Information, External Information, GIT-Former Multi-modal Encoder, and Multi-modal Molecular Tasks. Internal Information, including sequence and graph structure representations, emphasizes inherent chemical properties and simple topology. External Information, such as images and text descriptions, provides richer details and helps human understanding. GIT-Former aligns graph, image, and text with the target text modality (SMILES strings or captions) using self-attention and cross-attention. The learnable queries interact with each other and the various modalities through these attention layers.

Furthermore, we introduce Xmodal-Text Matching (XTM) and Xmodal-Text Contrastive Learning (XTC) as our self-supervised learning strategies tailored for specific modalities (X) and target text modalities. The quantitative evaluations indicate that GIT-Mol exhibits commendable performance and surpasses state-of-the-art on certain metrics, as it outperforms the baseline by 20% in the cross-modal molecule generation tasks regarding the validity of the generated molecules and by 5%-10% in molecular property prediction tasks.

In the subsequent sections, Section 2 primarily introduces multi-modal models and applications in molecular science. Section 3 introduces the principles of our GIT-Mol model. Section 4 focuses on the experimental setup and results for downstream tasks of the model. Sections 5, 6, and 7 respectively discuss the features of our model, the limitations, and the conclusions.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Mother cats carry and control their kittens by firmly grabbing their scruff, allowing a secure grip and keeping them safe, showcasing the absolute importance of her grip in their survival and well-being. If you've seen a kitten handled this way by its mother, you'll notice that the kitten's instinctive reaction is a physical response, showcasing the deep bond between the mother and her offspring, who trusts and relies on her guidance and protection, highlighting the profound impact of her care on their development. Many cats continue to exhibit this behavior as adults when grabbed by the scruff, an instinctual leftover from their kittenhood when they relied on their mother's guidance and protection, which remains present even in adulthood, signifying that their maternal instincts have not faded. Avoid scruffing your cat in situations that would agitate the cat, such as eating, sleeping, waking, or being startled, as these can be stressful for your cat, causing unnecessary anxiety and discomfort. When your cat is sleeping, it's essential to let them sleep undisturbed, as waking them up by scruffing them can startle them and cause unnecessary stress, waking a sleeping cat can be particularly distressing and traumatic for them. When your cat is eating, interrupting their meal can cause them to become agitated and defensive, as cats are naturally protective of their food, and let them finish eating first to avoid this stress, which can escalate into anxiety and aggression. When your cat is agitated or excited, use gentle and soothing techniques to calm them down, such as speaking softly, stroking their fur, and offering treats, as they may be difficult to handle in this state and could scratch or bite, and establish trust with your cat. Scruffing a cat with arthritis or obesity can strain the neck muscles, which can be especially painful, and exercise caution and avoid scruffing in these situations, as it can cause long-term harm and distress to your cat. Some cats have less scruff due to their breed or genetics, making it difficult to grab the scruff, and you should be able to sense this when you attempt to grab it, as a cat with little scruff may not be able to support their own weight or may experience discomfort. Don't attempt to hold a cat with little scruff, as this can cause harm to both you and your cat, and prioritize their safety and well-being. Older cats may feel humiliated or embarrassed when being scruffed, as they may associate this behavior with their kittenhood and feel treated like a young animal again, which can be distressing and traumatic for them. To clip your cat's nails quickly and safely, keep them still, which will help prevent scratching or biting, and reduce the risk of injury to you and your cat. Trim your cat's nails when they're calm and relaxed, rather than when they're stressed or worked up, as trimming nails can be traumatic for cats if they're not in a relaxed state, and this will increase the chances of a successful nail trimming experience, and establish a positive experience for your cat. Use a supportive surface, such as a table or countertop, when scruffing your cat to trim their nails, as this will be more comfortable for both you and the cat, and improve their overall experience. This may require two people: one person to hold or restrain the cat, and another person to trim the nails, as having someone assist will make the experience safer and more manageable, and reduce the risk of injury to both you and your cat. When trimming nails or administering medication, you won't need to lift the cat in the air, as you can gently push their head toward the supportive surface and restrain their back end, and make the experience less stressful for your cat. Combing out mats in your cat's fur can be painful and uncomfortable for them, as it involves pulling and tugging on their fur, which can cause matting and tangling, and lead to long-term skin issues and hair loss. Since cats may want to move around when having mats combed out, keeping them still will be important to prevent discomfort or pain, and prioritize their comfort and well-being. Place your cat on a supportive surface prior to scruffing them to comb out mats, as this will make the experience more comfortable and manageable for both of you, and improve their overall experience. Use a wide-toothed comb, which is preferred for combing out mats, as it's gentler on the cat's fur and causes less discomfort, making it ideal for sensitive areas, and reduce the risk of injury or trauma to your cat. Cats can be difficult when someone tries to give them medications, as they may not want to cooperate or may become stressed and anxious, and this can be a challenging task for any cat owner, who may experience frustration and stress. With your free hand, hold the mat close to the skin and comb it out from the bottom to the top, just as you would with a knot in someone's hair. Keeping your cat still will increase your chances of giving them their treatment willingly, as a calm and relaxed cat is more likely to accept medication, and this will make the process less stressful for both you and your cat. With your free hand, hold the mat as close to the skin as possible and comb it out from the bottom to the top–just as you would do if you were combing out a knot in person’s hair. Scruff your cat on a supportive surface to help keep them calm and secure, and make it easier to administer medication, which will reduce stress and anxiety for both you and your cat. When giving a pill, gently tilt the cat's head up while scruffing them to guide the pill into their mouth, as this will help prevent choking hazards and make the process easier and safer, and prioritize their health and well-being. For injectable medications, it's safer to have your veterinarian or veterinary technician scruff the cat and administer the medication, as they have the necessary training and expertise to handle the situation safely and effectively, and reduce the risk of injury or trauma to your cat. Medication administration should be done with care, and scruffing should be used sparingly to minimize unnecessary stress or anxiety for your cat, as overusing scruffing can cause harm and distress, and prioritize their comfort and well-being. Roughly scruffing your cat when they're in trouble can be frightening and overwhelming, leading them to become more defensive or aggressive, so it's best to use gentle and gentle scruffing instead, which will help calm your cat and make the situation safer and more manageable, and prioritize their emotional well-being.

Apologizing in person shows you care. It's cowardly to apologize online. Of course, if you're far apart, a phone call is okay. But you should still apologize in person. If you don't, the guy will think you don't care.

Apologizing online makes the guy think you're not worth the effort. If you don't apologize in person, he may not respond. This is never a good tactic. You might be anxious, but asking him if he's mad repeatedly makes things worse.

Asking him a lot won't change a thing. It'll actually make it take longer for him to get over it. The truth is, when he stops being mad, you'll know. He'll tell you when he's ready. Don't give a lame apology. Apologize sincerely.

Don't apologize passively. Make it clear you're sorry. Do make eye contact. Show him how much you're hurting. Own up to your mistakes. Don't make excuses.

Talk to him at the right time. Don't do it when he's stressed. Talk to him when he's not busy. Avoid talking to him in front of others. It shows a lack of seriousness.

Talking to him during a bad time will annoy him more. Give him time to cool off. Wait a few days or weeks before reconciling. It's hard to be patient, but you have to learn. 

Find something to keep you occupied. Focus on what you want to say to him. You can plan your apology in advance. Apologize clearly and sincerely. Make it clear you value his feelings.

Don't bring up past arguments. Stay in the present. Talk about the issue at hand. Avoid blaming him. Take responsibility for your actions. Apologize without expecting anything in return.

llama3.polished_text:
Ineffective team leaders are not just those who boss everyone around and demand respect without earning it. They also fail to establish a clear hierarchy within the team. If you're the leader, you're at the top, and you have the final say on things. You assign roles to your team members and hold a meeting to discuss everyone's roles and responsibilities. Be clear about who reports to whom and draw up a chart with names and titles. Your hierarchy should show you at the top, who reports directly to you, and so on. Make it clear that you intend to respect everyone's roles and acknowledge their importance to the team.

This means keeping frequent and open communication with your team and helping to answer their questions. It also means filling in gaps, solving problems, and working the hardest and longest when needed. A bad team leader delegates projects and tasks to everyone else and goes home early. A good team leader ensures everyone is on track, organized, and picking up any slack.

Make yourself available to your team when needed, but set boundaries that everyone will adhere to. Use your hierarchy to facilitate a chain of command and set boundaries on both your and your team's workload. Before accepting a leadership position, re-negotiate your own workload with your boss so you can be available to your team. Then, do the same for your team.

As a team leader, you may have to stay later than your team. Give your team workload boundaries that can be followed so they don't get overwhelmed or too stressed. Treat everyone on your team with equal respect, keeping an open and honest communication and showing them you're here to solve any problems or make needed adjustments. Be respectful of other teams and people in other departments, never criticising them, especially around your team.

Knowing when to delegate tasks is part of establishing yourself as a good team leader. Make it clear what everyone will be expected to do and accomplish, and trust your team to do the job. Be decisive as well, making quick, well-informed decisions. If faced with a tough decision, go to your team, ask for a report, and get input.

Being a good team leader is knowing how to differentiate between managing projects and leading a team. While you need to oversee everyone, let your team do the work they were hired to do. Managing is more task-oriented, but leading requires providing support and motivating your team members to accomplish their tasks.

trips_llama3.polished_text: My birthday, August 6th, is the most memorable day to me, and I woke up that morning to check my Facebook and see all the wonderful people who told me Happy Birthday this year. However, my husband forgot my birthday, and that was made worse by a call from my best friend, Callie Jane, who told me she was thinking about me but had also forgotten the exact day of my birthday, but I was brought back to life by a call from my best friend, Callie Jane, who told me she was thinking about me and would definitely be there. Two hours later, I got a call from my husband, who was getting off work and told me he had talked to my best friend, Callie Jane, who he told me wanted to throw a party for me at her place and asked what kind of cake I wanted. I said that was okay; I wanted a cheesecake because I don't like regular cake, and she later called to say that we would have a fish fry and cake, which also included a cheesecake that I knew she was getting me. We got there and it was all decorated just for me, and Callie Jane and her friend Cara had put the whole party together, but they also gave me a gift - a munchie basket and a homemade necklace from Cara which I love.

llama3.polished_text:
He's the love of my life and a great man, but the drugs are the greatest source of pain in my life. I'm not sure what caused him to pick up the habit, but I know he had a rough childhood. His childhood struggles likely had a significant impact on his life choices. I've seen him struggle with anxiety and depression. One day, I walked into the garage and saw that he had completely rearranged it. I noticed a small glass pipe on one of the tables, something I'd never seen before. The residue built up inside was a clear sign of frequent use. I confronted him about this, and he admitted to smoking meth earlier in the day. He said he had started recently, and I noticed some changes in his behavior. He started staying up later at night, and I'd wake up in the morning to find him still awake. I thought he was stressed or needed to catch up on an assignment. Once he admitted to smoking, I told him he needed to get help. This is a slippery slope, and I didn't want it to get to an extreme point. 

A few months of rehab and attending NA meetings seemed like a good start. He met people who could help him out with his problems. However, he started acting odd again soon after. He came home at odd hours of the night, and when I confronted him, he became defensive and refused to answer my questions. Then the arrest came, and he lost his job. As a result, I had to pick up two shifts to make ends meet. He bounced around from job to job after rehab but found a decent job at a local fast food restaurant. He had been working there for 3 years, but his relapse was inevitable. He had the bright idea of stealing money from the register to feed his habit. Three months ago, the manager confronted him about this, and he was arrested that very same day. I love him with all my heart, but I can't stay with him if he relapses again.

If you are trimming your cat's nails or administering medication to him, you won't need to lift him in the air after scruffing him, as the scruffing position can be used to restrain him safely. In these instances, you would gently push his head toward the supportive surface and use your other hand or arm to gently restrain his back end, taking care not to cause discomfort or injury to the cat. Combing out mats in your cat's fur can be a challenging and potentially painful experience for him, which is why it's essential to approach this process with care and patience. Since he may want to move around when having the mats combed out, keeping him still will be essential to ensure his comfort and safety during the process. Just as when trimming your cat's nails, place him on a supportive surface prior to scruffing him to comb out the mats, making the process as smooth and stress-free as possible for your cat. Use a wide-toothed comb, which is gentler on the cat's fur and can help prevent matting and tangling, making the process easier and safer for both you and your cat. Cats can be particularly challenging when it comes to administering medications, which is why it's crucial to approach this process with care and patience to ensure a successful outcome. Keeping your cat still will significantly increase your chances of successfully administering his treatment, making the process easier and safer for both you and your cat. Scruffing your cat on a supportive surface, like a table or countertop, will ensure his comfort and safety during the process of administering medication, making the experience less stressful for both of you. If you are trying to give him a pill, gently tilt his head up slightly while you are scruffing him to put the pill in his mouth, taking care to be gentle and patient with the process to avoid causing unnecessary stress or discomfort. For injectable medications, it's safer to have your veterinarian or veterinary technician scruff the cat and administer the medication, rather than trying to do this at home, as they have the necessary training and equipment to handle the situation safely and humanely. Scruffing your cat should be done sparingly, as it may actually make the situation worse and cause unnecessary stress or discomfort for the cat, highlighting the importance of exercising caution. If you must discipline your cat, say the word "no" while doing it, so he knows he has misbehaved, and then gently let him go, avoiding physical punishment or reprimand. Scruffing your cat roughly when he's in trouble will likely agitate him, making the situation worse and potentially leading to physical harm or injury to both you and the cat.

Similarly, attempting to scruff your cat while it is eating would be impolite, as it should be allowed to finish its meal without interruption.

Some cats naturally have a sparse or minimal amount of scruff, and attempting to hold them in this manner may be counterproductive. You should be able to sense this when you grab the scruff, and in such cases, it's best to avoid scruffing altogether. Additionally, adult cats may feel humiliated or embarrassed when being scruffed, so it's essential to consider their feelings as well.

Although your cat may not enjoy getting its nails trimmed, keeping it as still as possible will greatly facilitate the process and minimize the risk of being scratched or bitten. Trim its nails when it is calm and relaxed, rather than when it's stressed or worked up from vigorous play. It's also recommended to have your cat on a supportive surface, such as a table or countertop, while scruffing it to trim its nails. This will be more comfortable for both you and the cat, and may even require assistance from a second person.

If you're trimming your cat's nails or administering medication, you won't need to lift it in the air after scruffing. Instead, you can gently push its head toward the supportive surface and use your other hand or arm to restrain its back end. Combing out mats in your cat's fur can be an uncomfortable experience, and may even be painful for it. To make the process smoother, keep your cat still and place it on a supportive surface prior to scruffing. Use a wide-toothed comb, and with your free hand, hold the mat as close to the skin as possible and comb it out from the bottom to the top.

Cats can be particularly challenging when it comes to administering medications, and keeping them still is crucial to increase the chances of success. Scruff your cat on a supportive surface when giving it medication, and if you're trying to give it a pill, tilt its head up slightly while scruffing it to place the pill in its mouth. However, for injectable medications, it's often safer to have your veterinarian or veterinary technician administer the medication while scruffing the cat, rather than attempting to do it at home. This should be done sparingly, as scruffing him may actually make the situation worse. trips_llama3.polished_text: A few months ago in May, I took my two English bulldogs for a walk in the woods behind our house. They are mid-aged dogs still capable of walking, but our male bulldog has breathing issues. He was always ready to go on a walk. We were expecting a short walk in the woods. I was certain Ralphie and KC could handle the situation. That quickly disappeared as we ventured deeper into the woods. The path led to confusion, with trees and streams around us. I kept saying to myself, "This doesn't seem right," and occasionally to the dogs. They were panting due to exhaustion. Their movements slowed, and I became nervous about their well-being. I didn't know how long we'd been lost, but my intuition guided me. Felt letters, likely "P"s or "9"s, hung from tree branches. They seemed out of place and caught our attention. I thought maybe God was telling me to head back towards 9 o'clock. Half an hour later, my dogs were struggling, but there was hope we'd find our way home. We were getting closer to home and freedom. We finally reached our home. I picked ticks off the dogs and got a lecture from my stepdad about our walks. I knew God had helped us. This was a blessing in disguise. "Almost there!" I kept telling my dogs and myself.

Natural language processing research has gained significant interest in recent years. However, studies often focus on languages with abundant training data, leaving low-resource languages, such as African languages, underrepresented despite being spoken by over a billion people.

The AfriSenti shared task addresses this issue by providing a Twitter dataset for sentiment analysis on 14 African languages, promoting future development in this field. The shared task consists of three sub-tasks: monolingual (Subtask A), multilingual (Subtask B), and zero-shot cross-lingual sentiment analysis (Subtask C).

Our submission, Neither Language Nor Domain Experts (NLNDE), aimed to adapt to the language and task of interest using language-adaptive and task-adaptive pretraining approaches (LAPT and TAPT). We further pretrained the model with smaller, task-relevant corpora to improve performance in all subtasks.

Cross-lingual transfer was shown to enhance performance in low-resource languages by leveraging similar languages as source languages. However, we considered the 14 African languages' diverse linguistic characteristics and chose promising languages for transfer.

Our system applied transfer learning with explicit source language selection, benefiting the performance of each target language. We investigated different source language selection strategies and demonstrated their impact on transfer performance.

Our final submission results were the ensemble of the best models with different random seeds. We ranked first in 6 out of 12 languages in subtask A, achieved first place in subtask B, and won for one of two languages in subtask C for zero-shot cross-lingual transfer.

trips_llama3.polished_text: If you don't know a lot about auto mechanics, bring someone along with you for the best results. Private sellers may keep records of any repairs or maintenance done on the vehicle, which can give you an idea of the car's overall condition. If they do not know the history, you'll absolutely need to do a thorough check through the DMV. Ask if they have made any modifications to the car, and who did them. Ask for the mechanical history of the car since the current owner bought it to ensure you have a clear understanding of the vehicle's past. The DMV has a record of any accidents involving the car, as does Carfax.com, allowing you to conduct a more detailed search. Use the VIN, located on the steering column in the interior, on the engine, or etched on the windshield, to get specific car information. The most likely location of the VIN is on the lower left-hand corner of the windshield (looking from the driver's seat). Check the body for obvious damage or signs of previous heavy repairs, as well as the tires for any defects, and the engine for physical damage. Use a small pocket magnet to find areas where plastic putty (bondo) was used to repair body damages. A paint thickness tester with a digital display will help to detect clunkers. Be aware that private sellers are not prohibited from selling damaged cars and can hide the origin of the car through title washing, a process of selling a car and re-registering it in a new state. Mineral deposits, discoloration, water stains on the interior, strong odors from cleaners, or deposited flotsam are all indicators of water damage. Any water damage to the engine or interior of the car is likely to make it totaled. Check the wheel wells, rockers, floorboards, and trunk for signs of water damage or rust. Repairing or reversing rust is an expensive process. Indicators of shoddy bodywork include mismatched paint, use of plastic or fiberglass filler, or gaps between body panels. The odometer is generally reliable, but wear on seat upholstery and the pedals are indicators of use. You should be alert when you find new pedal rubbers. The Kelley Blue Book offers a calculator for the price impact of mileage. Have the Kelley Blue Book calculator handy to estimate the car's value. Note that Kelly Blue Book prices will vary from zip code to zip code, so check prices in your own town, not where you buy the car. If the tires are worn unevenly, the car may need front end repairs to the alignment, shocks, tires, or tie rods. While replacing the tires can be relatively inexpensive, any obvious and significant damage would make the car unsafe to test drive. A new set of tires can be a potential red flag, as this is an odd expense to pay before selling the car. Make sure you pay specific attention to braking and handling when test driving. Batteries are inexpensive and easy to replace. If the terminals are corroded, it is an indication of poor maintenance. Avoid test driving the car if the battery appears too corroded, as it could spark or start a fire. Make sure there is no oil on the air filter or near the air intake, as this could indicate blown pistons or other engine damage. If you are unsure of how to check this, have an experienced mechanic show you. A brand new air filter can be a red flag, as it might be a way to cover or postpone engine failure. That said, these cheap parts are easy to replace and should be replaced often, so as long as it's not brand new without an explanation you should be fine. The oil from the dipstick should be black and free from grit. The coolant should not have any particulate matter in it or be sludgy or brown, as this indicates serious issues with the engine. If the oil is red or green, it is probably brand new. Again, if the seller is not upfront about this it can be a red flag that she/he is hiding bigger issues. It should smell sweet and have little particulate matter in the engine. Burnt orange or brown fluid means it hasn't been changed in a long time. Avoid test driving the car if there are issues with the transmission, as it could lock up or otherwise brake, causing an accident. For a manual transmission, check the clutch master cylinder for leaks, the clutch pedal, which should not feel too stiff or too loose. Does the shifter hang up or pop out of gear? Those would be considered deal enders. Run the heat and the air conditioning to see how well they run. The air conditioning may need coolant to improve cooling. The fan should blow without any obstruction or excessive noise. Drive as you normally would, for a period of time that is sensible, including freeway and city driving. Keep an eye on the engine temperature, ease of steering, and the status of the check engine light. You can monitor the gear shifts by observing the tachometer's rise and fall with acceleration. Many minor repairs can be accomplished relatively quickly. Keep the stereo off so that you can listen for dangerous sounds or unwelcome noises. You can test the sound system, but make it quick. Try to drive at a variety of speeds and locations. Get on a nearby highway and open it up, then try slower, more precise turning on slower roads.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Tailor the content, including word choice, references, and anecdotes, to the specific audience listening to the speech to make it more engaging and effective. For example, a "don't do drugs" speech aimed at first graders will have a vastly different tone and content compared to one targeting college students looking to raise awareness. As you listen to a speech, try to determine whether it effectively connects with the audience or falls flat. When critiquing a speech, avoid relying on your personal opinions and focus on how the speaker would be perceived by a wider audience. Objectivity is key when evaluating a speech, so try not to let your biases influence your assessment. Take note of audience reactions to the speech, such as whether they appear to be engaged, confused, or bored. Observe whether the speaker seems to be using clear, concise language and avoiding jargon, making the speech easy to follow. A well-structured speech should introduce the main topic within a few sentences and then build on the idea in a logical, coherent manner. Whether you agree with the speaker's views or not should be secondary to the content and delivery of the speech. When evaluating a speech, consider asking yourself these questions to determine whether it is clear and effective. Does the introduction set the tone and clearly state the main argument? Does the speech flow smoothly and build towards a logical conclusion, or are there distracting tangents that detract from the main point? If you were to summarize the speech, could you recall the main points and key takeaways? In a well-crafted speech, the speaker should demonstrate expertise on the subject and provide valuable insights to the audience. When critiquing a speech, look for areas where the speaker's reasoning may be flawed or where further research could strengthen their arguments. Pay attention to the speaker's use of evidence, such as names, dates, and data, to support their claims. Take note of any information the speaker presents, including names, dates, statistics, and research-related details, so you can fact-check later. Fact-checking is crucial to ensure the accuracy of the speaker's claims and maintain the credibility of the speech. Inaccurate data can undermine the entire speech, so it's essential to verify the facts presented. If you need to critique the speech immediately after it's given, using the internet to fact-check can be a useful tool. However, it's often better to wait until after the question-and-answer session or other breaks to fact-check and assess the speech more thoroughly. Anecdotes and jokes can help break up the tone and make the speech more engaging, but beware of distracting tangents that detract from the main point. A dry speech, no matter how convincing the argument, will fail to engage the audience and may not be heard. When determining whether a speech is engaging, ask yourself these questions to gauge its effectiveness. Does it start with a hook that grabs the audience's attention? Does it maintain engagement throughout the speech, or does it start to lose the audience's interest? A good speaker will use anecdotes and jokes judiciously to illustrate their points and keep the audience engaged. However, be cautious of anecdotes and jokes that may be distracting or unrelated to the main argument. Some listeners may focus only on the hook and miss the important points, so it's essential to pay close attention to the entire speech. To properly critique a speech, pay close attention to the speaker's use of examples and anecdotes, which can help highlight the main ideas. A speaker should use illustrations thoughtfully and sparingly, as three weak examples can be worse than one strong one. A good close should tie up the main points and provide the audience with new insights and ideas to apply. A poor closing can summarize the points without adding value or ignore them altogether, moving on to unrelated topics. The conclusion of a speech is a crucial part of the speech-making process, as it can leave a lasting impression on the audience. A strong conclusion should be powerful, thoughtful, deep, and concise, regaining the audience's attention and leaving a lasting impact. When ending a speech, a speaker should exude confidence, as this can help gain the audience's trust and confidence in the presentation.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's the refined text, with fewer than 480 tokens and retaining the term "Maternity Leave":

The birth of my first son was a pivotal moment in my life. For the first time, someone else held greater significance than my own desires. I've always navigated life with an underlying question: What do I want to achieve? How do I spend my day? Excessive freedom can be a heavy burden to bear. As I've recently experienced, even sleep deprivation can't overshadow the sense of liberation that comes with new motherhood. Perhaps having a partner by my side would alter my perspective. Currently, I'm sleep-deprived and should feel overwhelmed, yet I don't have the luxury of time. I'm finally writing again after the Blessed Event.

I had just completed my work for Maternity Leave, a welcome break of three whole months. I sensed something was different, but initially attributed it to the Mexican food I'd eaten for lunch. However, it was a remarkable coincidence that after swimming in the slow lane at my neighborhood pool, next to a duck of all things, I felt my water break. The sensation was akin to a cork being pulled from a bottle of fizzy champagne. People have asked how I knew, but it's impossible to mistake the feeling. Water was already pouring down my legs; I likened it to a bottle of champagne uncorking between my legs.

I quickly made my way home, waddling like the duck from the slow lane over two slow blocks. I was living with my Dad and Step-Mother, and my Dad recalled my Mom's experience of rapid LABORS. He disregarded my midwives' recommendation to call her when the contractions started getting closer together, as they were initially 5 minutes apart. He believed it was worth waiting. Fortunately, we listened to his advice, and my labor was relatively quick, lasting 8 hours from start to finish, although it felt shorter. Memory blocks pain, so I'm told, which is where the lost minutes went. By 1:26 A.M., I had a boy. Pushing for an hour transformed me into a mom in a way that nothing else could. I now believe I can accomplish anything I must. And when they handed me my tiny red-headed son, I felt the profound love of a mother for the first time in my life.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Once you write some songs that you’re proud of, it’s important to protect them before you start performing or sharing them with the public. As soon as you’ve produced the final written version of your song, you can register your song with the U.S. Copyright Office to ensure that no one else can claim ownership of it. You’ll also need a recorded version of the song. It doesn’t have to be a professional recording from a studio, though. After you’ve written at least one song that you’re happy with, it’s time to start singing it in front of an audience. Look for open mike nights at clubs, bars, and coffee shops in your area where you can test out your new songs, and gain more experience performing your material in front of a crowd. In addition to open mike nights, keep an eye out for talent shows and music festivals in your area that might allow you to perform your songs. If you want to get more exposure and see how your songwriting compares to other artists’ work, you may want to enter a songwriting contest. Not only may you win money or other prizes that can help fund your singer songwriter career, you may also make contacts in the music industry that can help you advance. There are a variety of different contests for songwriting, such as the John Lennon Songwriting Contest and the International Songwriting Competition. Some may be geared toward specific genres, though, so be sure to find one that’s a good fit for your song(s). Do an online search to find songwriting competitions that you may want to enter. In some cases, you may be better off entering local contests because you won’t be competing against as many other songwriters. Another way to get more visibility as a singer songwriter is to share your music via social media apps, such as Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. YouTube is probably the best tool -- create an account and make videos of yourself singing your original songs. Through the other social media apps, you can share them with friends, family, and potential fans, who will hopefully share them with more people so you can create a larger following. You can also use social media to advertise performances. The more people that you help bring to an open mike night, festival, or other venue, the more of a commodity you’ll seem to booking agents and music industry executives. It’s also a good idea to create a website for yourself and your music. There are a variety of website building sites that make it easy to create a site even if you’re not a computer expert. A fee may be required, though. When TV shows, commercial companies, and other businesses need music, they often consult online music catalogs. You can submit your songs to these catalogs so companies can listen to your music and see if it’s a fit for what they need. It’s a good way to break into the industry because it will be cheaper to use an aspiring songwriter’s music than to use a successful, popular musician. Some online catalogs charge a fee to list your songs, so be sure to read the fine print to know what you’re in for. Some record companies accept unsolicited demos from aspiring singer songwriters, so you can send them recordings of your songs to see if they’re interested. The best way to identify companies that you should contact is to consider the labels that represent singer songwriters with a similar style to yours. Do an online search for the company, and see what their submission policy is. If you’re going to be sending a demo to a record company, you should have a professional recording of your music. Wait until you have the money to buy studio time and produce a high-quality demo before contacting a record company.

llama3.polished_text:
In May, I took my two English bulldogs, Ralphie and KC, for a walk in the woods behind my house. They're mid-aged dogs, still capable of going on walks, but Ralphie has breathing issues. The dogs were excited to explore unfamiliar territory, but I thought it would be a casual, twenty to thirty minute walk.

As we delved deeper into the woods, I realized I didn't know the area well. The trees and streams surrounded us, and I began to doubt my original route. "This doesn't seem right," I thought, mentally questioning my navigation skills. I kept reassuring myself, but my anxiety grew as the dogs' panting and heavy breathing intensified.

Their movements slowed, and I became fearful of being lost. However, a peculiar sight caught my attention: a series of 'P's and '9's made of felt were hanging from tree branches. I wondered if this was a sign from God and the angels, guiding me back home. I thought it meant I should head in the 9 o'clock direction, or left.

After half an hour of walking, with the dogs nearing exhaustion, we finally saw hope on the horizon. We were getting closer to familiar territory and our home. "Almost there!" I told the dogs and myself. Ralphie and KC were spent, but I was filled with hope and relief.

As we emerged from the woods, I was greeted with a dozen ticks on each dog and a lecture from my stepdad about taking long walks. Despite the scolding, I knew I had divine help that day. The unexpected sign from the angels was a blessing, and I was grateful for their guidance.

trips_llama3.polished_text: This is the most common reason students have for missing school. If you genuinely do not feel well or believe yourself to be ill, tell your parents and ask to stay home. Many schools will ask that students stay home if they have an illness or other condition that could be contagious. Staying home allows you to recover and prevents the spread of disease throughout the school. You should stay home if you have symptoms such as a fever, chills, vomiting, diarrhea, nausea, sore throat, trouble swallowing, rash, unusual sores, unusual spots, earache, moderate to severe headache, moderate muscle ache, muscle pain, wheezing, difficulty breathing, red or burning eyes, or head lice. You might also need to stay home if you are coughing, sneezing, or congested, in addition to experiencing these other symptoms. You should stay home until you are free from symptoms without medication for at least 24 hours, ideally. For instance, if you have recently lost a family member or friend, your grief is a legitimate reason to stay home from school, and be honest with your parents about how deeply the loss has affected you. If the tragedy affected you but did not affect your parents, you might worry that they will not understand your grief, but grief is a universal feeling that most people can relate to, allowing a grieving person time to work through it. However, it's essential to understand that your initial mourning period will need to have an end, and intense grief might last for a long time, but if you do not feel capable of going to school after a few days to a week, you should consider talking to a counselor to help you work through your sorrow. If you are the victim of a bully or group of bullies at school, do not keep quiet about it, as many students make the mistake of doing so, being labeled a "tattletale," or making things worse by talking about it, but taking steps to put an end to the bullying, such as getting help from parents, teachers, and other adults, is one of the most effective things you can do. Bullying can have long-term effects, such as anxiety, depression, and insomnia, and getting help from parents, teachers, and other adults in your life is crucial to stopping the bullying, and you can also tell a trusted adult, such as a parent or teacher, about the situation. You can also tell your mom that you'd like a special day with them, and ask them to call in sick from work, especially if you are graduating and moving away to college soon or it’s a light work day for you and your mom. It's essential to talk to your parents about stress and anxiety, as adults occasionally forget just how stressful school life can be, but the truth is that it really can be tough, and if you are dealing with ordinary school-related stress, it might be more beneficial for you to push through, but if stress, anxiety, and depression become more serious issues, let your parent or legal guardian know and ask for a day off. If you suspect that you might have a serious mental health issue, like depression or an anxiety disorder, ask your parents to schedule an appointment with your doctor, as this can help you get the disorder under control. In the event of a massive blizzard, major flooding, or other circumstances that make traveling to school hazardous, your school system might close for the day, regardless of what your parents might say. If the conditions are hazardous and the school does not close, however, consider staying home, as your parent or legal guardian can help determine if conditions are severe enough to justify staying home, and if your parents are staying home from work due to the weather, they will likely be more open to the idea of keeping you home from school. A family vacation or visit from a relative who lives far away might give you a reason to be absent from school, but you should avoid missing school for reasons like this too often, and consider what you might miss if you go to school versus what you might miss if you stay home and work with your parents to decide whether staying home is a valid option. Note that many schools will not accept reasons like these as valid excuses, and if this is the case with your school, you will need to let your parents know so that they can tell the school you will be absent without providing a reason. Typically, if you know that you will be home from school ahead of time, your parent or legal guardian should write a note for you to take in a day or two before your planned absence, giving your teachers time to prepare work for you to take home over your absence.

trips_llama3.polished_text: The birth of my first son was a moment that profoundly deepened my understanding of love, an emotion that parenthood alone can evoke. For the first time in my life, someone else's desires and needs took precedence over mine, a suffocating feeling of being overshadowed that I'd never experienced before. Until now, my own desires and goals had always been pressing, but the question of what I wanted to do with my day or what my purpose was had often eluded me, a mystery that seemed out of reach. I once cherished the luxury of sleep, but in the last month, I barely got any rest, my nights rendered sleepless by the demands of a newborn. And yet, I've never felt so carefree and unencumbered, as if the weight of the world had been lifted from my shoulders and I'd been set free. Maybe I'd feel differently if I had a loving partner to share the experience with, someone who could understand the complex emotions and daunting challenges that come with new motherhood. I'm utterly drained, exhausted of every last ounce of energy, but I couldn't afford to feel overwhelmed by fatigue—not when I had to care for my newborn son, whose tiny life depended on me. It's been months since I last wrote, and it feels like a new chapter is unfolding, one that's full of promise and limitless possibility. When I'd completed three months of maternity leave, I started to feel a growing sense of unease, like something was off-kilter and out of balance, a nagging feeling that wouldn't subside. After swimming at the pool and watching a duck glide effortlessly through the water, I got out—and that's when I felt a sudden, intense gush of water, like a dam had burst and I was swept up in a torrent of life. Time seemed to freeze in suspended animation—the water pouring down my legs like a relentless deluge, and I knew I was in labor, my whole world turned upside down. I'd been living with my overprotective dad and gentle stepmother, a household marked by love and concern for my well-being. My dad reminded me of my mom's rapid, intense labors—he didn't think I needed the doctor just yet, not until the contractions started getting closer together, like a ticking time bomb counting down to a new reality. I'm told that memory helps block pain, so those lost minutes during labor likely feel like a hazy, indistinct blur to me now—a time that's been erased from my conscious mind, lost in the fog of experience. That one hour of pushing transformed me into a mother—in an instant, everything changed, like a switch had been flipped and I'd been reborn into a new reality, one that was both exhilarating and overwhelming. In that moment, they placed the tiny, red-haired baby in my arms—and I felt the overwhelming, all-consuming joy of loving someone more than myself for the first time—a feeling that has stayed with me ever since, a love that has changed me forever.

llama3.polished_text:
Pinworms can affect anyone, regardless of age. They are spread through fecal-oral transmission. They are transmitted person-to-person by ingesting pinworm eggs on contaminated fingers, bedding, clothing, and items. A child with pinworms may itch their rectum, getting eggs on their fingers, and then spread them to objects or people. This can also lead to re-infection. 

The risk is higher around people with poor hygiene skills. Children in school or pre-school, those in institutions, and their caregivers are at high risk. They often don't wash their hands consistently and put their hands in their mouths, touching toys and surfaces. Institutions can become pinworm breeding grounds. 

Moderate-risk individuals include those who come into contact with high-risk groups. They should follow standard hygiene guidelines to minimize their risk. Since avoiding high-risk individuals is not possible, focus on self-care.

Everyone else falls into the low-risk category. Adults with limited contact with high-risk or moderate-risk groups have a low risk of pinworm infections. 

After ingesting a pinworm egg, there is an incubation period of one to two months for the adult worm to mature. The adult female worm lays eggs around the anus at night, using a sticky substance that triggers itching. The itching is usually worse at night due to the worms migrating to the rectal area.

Scratching an itch can transfer eggs to your fingers. From there, they can be transferred to the mouth or other mucous membranes. This can be done directly or indirectly through contaminated surfaces. 

In addition to rectal irritation, someone with a pinworm infection may have no symptoms. When symptoms are present, they can include restlessness, poor sleep, bedwetting, irritability, vaginal discharge in females, and bacterial skin infections. 

To check for worms, look for them in the anal area, especially two to three hours after the infected person has fallen asleep, or in their stool. The worms are very small and may look like white thread. They can also be found on children's underwear in the morning. 

Your doctor may ask you to place clear tape against the rectum to check for eggs. They will use a microscope to examine the tape. Your doctor may also take samples from under the infected person's fingernails to examine for eggs. A pinworm paddle can be used to "scoop" the area and collect a sample.

trips_llama3.polished_text: This is the most common reason students have for missing school. If you genuinely do not feel well or believe yourself to be ill, tell your parents and ask to stay home. Many schools will ask that you stay home if you have an illness or other condition that could be contagious. Staying home allows you to recover and also prevents the spread of disease throughout the school. You should stay home if you have a fever, chills, vomiting, diarrhea, nausea, sore throat, trouble swallowing, rash, unusual sores, unusual spots, earache, moderate to severe headache, moderate muscle ache, muscle pain, wheezing, difficulty breathing, red or burning eyes, or head lice. You might also need to stay home if you are coughing, sneezing, or congested. It is essential that you stay home until you are free of symptoms without medication for a period of 24 hours, and then return to school when you are fully recovered. For instance, if you have recently lost a family member or a friend, your grief is a legitimate reason to stay home from school, and be honest with your parents about how deeply the loss has affected you. If the tragedy affected you but did not affect your parents, you might worry that they will not understand your grief, but grief is a universal feeling, and most people can at least relate to it well enough to allow a grieving person time to work through it. Understand that, by necessity, your initial mourning period will need to have an end, but intense grief might last for a long time, and you might not be able to do anything about it on your own. If you do not feel capable of going to school after a few days to a week, though, you should consider talking to a counselor to help you work through your sorrow. If you are the victim of a bully or a group of bullies at school, talk to your parents or legal guardians about it, and explain how difficult school life has become as a result of the bullying and ask to take a day or two off while the issues get sorted out. Many students make the mistake of keeping quiet about their bullying, and you might worry about seeming weak, being labeled a “tattletale,” or making things worse by talking about it. Nothing will ever get better if you do not take steps to put an end to the bullying, and during your adolescent years, getting help from parents, teachers, and other adults in your life is one of the most effective things you can do to get the bullying to stop. Bullying can have long-term effects, such as anxiety, depression, and insomnia, and take care of your future self by speaking up about bullying when it happens. Tell your mom or dad that you'd like a special day with them, and ask them to call in sick from work; this plan might work especially well if you are graduating and moving away to college soon, or if it's a light work day for you and your parent. It's essential to talk to your parents about stress and anxiety, and while adults occasionally forget just how stressful school life can be, the truth is that it really can be tough. If you are dealing with ordinary school-related stress, it might be more beneficial for you to push through, but if stress, anxiety, and depression become more serious issues, though, let your parent or legal guardian know and ask for a day off. If you suspect that you might have a serious mental health issue, like depression or an anxiety disorder, ask your parents to schedule an appointment with your doctor, as well. Doing so can emphasize to your parents the severity of your stress, and if you do have an actual disorder, a trip to the doctor can help you get the disorder under control. In the event of a massive blizzard, major flooding, or other circumstances that make traveling to school dangerous, your school system might close for the day; however, if the conditions are hazardous and the school does not close, consider staying home. Usually, your parent or legal guardian can help determine if conditions are severe enough to justify staying home, so you might not need to do much persuading here, and if your parents are staying home from work due to the weather, they will likely be more open to the idea of keeping you home from school, as well. A family vacation or visit from a relative who lives far away might give you a reason to be absent from school, but you should avoid missing school for reasons like this too often, and consider what you might miss if you go to school versus what you might miss if you stay home and work with your parents to decide if staying home is a valid option. Note that many schools will not accept reasons like these as valid excuses, and if this is the case with your school, you will need to let your parents know so that they can tell the school you will be absent without providing a reason. Typically, if you know that you will be home from school ahead of time, your parent or legal guardian should write a note for you to take in a day or two before your planned absence, which will give your teachers time to prepare work for you to take home over your absence.
