trips_llama3.polished_text: There is an increasing interest in building speech tools benefiting low-resource languages, specifically multilingual models that can improve low-resource recognition using rich resources available in other languages like English and Mandarin. One standard tool for recognition in low-resource languages is multilingual acoustic modeling. Acoustic models are generally trained on parallel data of speech waveforms and phoneme transcriptions, which involves the alignment of audio signals with their corresponding written transcriptions, providing a crucial step in understanding the complex relationship between sound and meaning. Importantly, phonemes are perceptual units of sound that closely correlate with but do not exactly correspond to the actual sounds that are spoken, phones. An example of this is shown in Figure 1, which demonstrates two English words that share the same phoneme /p/ but differ in the actual phonetic realizations [p] and [ph], highlighting the complexities of phonetic representation. Allophones are the sets of phones that correspond to a particular phoneme, and these sets are language-specific; distinctions that are important in some languages, such as the difference between the English phonemes /p/ and /ph/, are not important in others, such as Mandarin Chinese. Most multilingual acoustic models simply use existing phoneme transcriptions as-is, taking the union of the phoneme sets to be shared by all training languages, but this approach can be overly simplistic and may not account for the complexities of phonetic representation. The assumption is reasonable under some circumstances as phoneme names are typically associated with their most common or least marked allophone, but this is often determined by the phonetician's expertise and the specific language being studied. However, this is obviously an oversimplified view: in Figure 1, for example, this would mean that all training in English would assign the phones [p] and [ph] to phoneme /p/, which would be detrimental if we want to recognize Mandarin Chinese, for instance, where the two phones are corresponding to two distinctive phonemes /p/ and /ph/. In this paper, we propose a novel method for multilingual recognition based on phonetic annotation to tackle this problem, which we call Allosaurus (allophone system of automatic recognition for universal speech). Our method incorporates knowledge of phonology into the multilingual model through an allophone layer, which associates a universal narrow phone set with the phonemes that appear in the transcription of each language, providing a more nuanced understanding of phonetic representation. Our model first computes the phone distribution using a standard ASR encoder, then the allophone layer maps the phone distribution into the phoneme distribution for each language, allowing for a more accurate representation of phonetic relationships. This model can be trained end-to-end using only standard phonemic transcriptions and an allophone list created by expert phoneticians, who have a deep understanding of the complexities of phonetic representation and can provide a more accurate representation of phonetic relationships. The allophone layer is first initialized with the allophone list, then is further optimized during the training process, allowing the model to learn the complex relationships between phones and phonemes. We demonstrate that accounting for the phoneme-phone mismatch in this way improves the accuracy of multilingual acoustic modeling by 2.0% phoneme error rate in low-resource conditions, providing a significant improvement over previous approaches. Furthermore, the architecture simultaneously makes it possible to perform universal phone recognition, allowing for the recognition of phones in any language, regardless of the specific phonetic representation used. Previous approaches can be limited by their reliance on simplified representations of phonetic relationships, but our method provides a more nuanced understanding of phonetic representation, allowing for more accurate recognition of phones and phonemes in low-resource languages.

llama3.polished_text: There is an increasing interest in building speech tools that can benefit low-resource languages, specifically multilingual models that can improve low-resource speech recognition using rich resources available in other languages such as English and Mandarin. One standard tool for recognition in low-resource languages is multilingual acoustic modeling, a technique that has garnered significant attention in recent years. Acoustic models are generally trained on parallel data of speech waveforms and phoneme transcriptions, which are then used to predict the spoken words. Importantly, phonemes are perceptual units of sound that closely correlate with, but do not exactly correspond to, the actual sounds that are spoken, known as phones. For instance, the English language has a phoneme /p/ which can be realized as different phones such as [p] and [ph], as shown in Figure 1. An example of this is demonstrated in Figure 1, which shows two English words that share the same phoneme /p/, but differ in the actual phonetic realizations [p] and [ph]. Allophones are the sets of phones that correspond to a particular phoneme, and these sets are language-specific; distinctions that are important in some languages are not important in others. Most multilingual acoustic models simply use existing phoneme transcriptions as-is, taking the union of the phoneme sets to be shared by all training languages. However, this assumption is reasonable under some circumstances, as phoneme names are typically associated with their most common or least marked allophone. Nevertheless, this is an oversimplified view, as shown in Figure 1, where the phoneme /p/ in English would correspond to the phones [p] and [ph], which are distinct phonemes in Mandarin Chinese. In Mandarin Chinese, the two phones [p] and [ph] are corresponding to two distinctive phonemes /p/ and /ph/, which would be detrimental to recognition if we use the existing phoneme transcriptions as-is. In this paper, we propose a novel method for multilingual recognition based on phonetic annotation to tackle this problem, known as Allosaurus (allophone system of automatic recognition for universal speech). Our method incorporates knowledge of phonology into the multilingual model through an allophone layer, which associates a universal narrow phone set with the phonemes that appear in the transcription of each language. Our model first computes the phone distribution using a standard ASR encoder, then the allophone layer maps the phone distribution into the phoneme distribution for each language. This model can be trained end-to-end using only standard phonemic transcriptions and an allophone list created by phoneticians. The allophone layer is first initialized with the allophone list, then is further optimized during the training process. We demonstrate that accounting for the phoneme-phone mismatch in this way improves the accuracy of multilingual acoustic modeling by 2.0% phoneme error rate in low-resource conditions. Furthermore, the architecture simultaneously makes it possible to perform universal phone recognition, which is a significant advantage over previous approaches. Previous approaches can only recognize phonemes, but our method can recognize both phonemes and phones, making it a more comprehensive approach to speech recognition. Our approach can be applied to various languages, including English, Mandarin Chinese, and many others, making it a versatile tool for speech recognition. Additionally, our method can be used to improve the recognition of languages with complex phonology, such as Arabic and Russian, which have a large number of distinct phonemes and phones. By incorporating knowledge of phonology into the multilingual model, our method can better handle the phoneme-phone mismatch and improve the accuracy of speech recognition. The proposed method has several advantages over previous approaches, including improved accuracy, versatility, and comprehensiveness. Our method can be used in various applications, including speech recognition, language translation, and voice recognition, making it a valuable tool for researchers and practitioners in the field of natural language processing.

trips_llama3.polished_text: The frame is the base of the bike and can be one of the most expensive parts you can buy. Getting a new frame usually means buying a brand new bike -- unless you have amazing brakes, pedals, gears, and handlebars on your old bike, it is rarely cost effective to buy a new frame and transfer everything over. When shopping for frames, there is a definite hierarchy in frame weight. Carbon fiber is the gold standard for lightweight bikes, but it is unfortunately a bit brittle. You'll often see it used in mountain bikes, as the technology has advanced over the years. Be cautious when purchasing a second-hand carbon bike, as the technology has evolved over time and the bike's condition may be uncertain. Racing, triathlon, and high-end road bikes are almost exclusively made with carbon fiber. Titanium is a high-end option that has the same stiffness as steel but is less dense. Titanium is often used in mountain and road bikes due to its high-end properties and durability. Aluminum: This strong and lightweight material is commonly used in bike frames due to its durability and affordability. They can be made as light as steel, but they won't be as lightweight as carbon fiber. Steel: This sturdy material is commonly used in older bikes due to its durability and affordability, but it can be heavier than other options. However, some custom steel bikes, especially those designed for racing, might still be under 20 lb (9.1 kg). One of the best 'bang for your buck' fixes is to upgrade to lighter wheels, which can improve aerodynamics and reduce weight. You'll not only lose weight, but you'll also become significantly more aerodynamic, making it easier to maintain high speeds and maneuver through tight spaces. Lower spoke-count wheels and wheels made of lighter material will all help lighten your bike. What constitutes an 'upgrade' depends on your current bike setup, but some sure-fire ways to reduce weight include upgrading to lighter wheels, using aerodynamic bars, and optimizing your drivetrain. Steel or carbon fiber wheels are good options, as they can provide significant weight reduction and improve aerodynamics. Tubular wheels are not recommended for casual riders, as they require special tires that are difficult to install and replace. Aero wheels can significantly reduce wind resistance and improve aerodynamics, making them a popular choice among serious cyclists. Mountain bike tires, which are designed for off-road use, are not suitable for paved hills and can cause significant discomfort and safety issues. If you ride more on roads than trails, consider commuter or 'cross' tires, which are designed for on-road use and can provide a smooth ride and improved handling. Slicks are a great option for light trails, such as footpaths, and can provide a smooth ride and improved handling. Examine your chain rings, which are the large metal gears located beside your right pedal and play a crucial role in your bike's performance. If you have three chain rings, consider upgrading to a 'compact crank,' which can provide improved efficiency and reduced weight. Carbon fiber bars or specialty aerodynamic bars, such as triathlon bars, can significantly reduce weight and dampen vibrations on bumpy roads, improving your overall ride comfort and performance. Remember that carbon fiber is somewhat brittle and prone to damage, so it's essential to have it checked at your local bike shop after any major crash or impact. Many bike accessories can add unnecessary weight, so it's essential to carefully evaluate their necessity and remove any unnecessary items. Remove any unnecessary accessories like saddlebags, lights, and fenders, especially when riding in dry conditions or on long distances, to reduce weight and improve aerodynamics. For short rides, consider removing extra water bottle cages, but always have at least one water bottle on hand, unless water is provided by the race or a designated water stop. These minor adjustments won't make a significant difference in weight, but they can still improve safety and visibility on busy roads by preserving bike lights and other essential features. For serious racers, lighter shoes and aero helmets can reduce weight, enhance performance, and give a competitive edge, while also looking professional and stylish. You can also upgrade to racing pedals and wear lightweight shoes designed to attach to them, which can provide improved power transfer and efficiency. For the most extreme cases, race trimming involves removing every gram of weight possible, which can be a challenging and time-consuming process. Jack Pullar, a professional rider, took an extreme approach by removing his seat covering, drilling holes in his saddle, and sawing off his handlebars to achieve significant weight reduction, but such modifications are not recommended for casual riders. While you should be cautious, some race modifications include removing the seat post, trimming cables, and upgrading to lighter components. Removing 1-2 inches from the seat post, leaving at least 2 1⁄2 in (6.4 cm) in the seat tube, is an acceptable modification that can reduce weight and improve aerodynamics. Trimming the ends of your cables and cable housings can be an effective modification that can reduce weight and improve aerodynamics. Removing water cages and bolts can be a simple and effective modification that can reduce weight and improve aerodynamics. Unless you're willing to invest in a high-end, 11lb bike costing $15,000, you won't experience significant weight loss, and the cost may not be justified. Swapping to a lighter group set (gears) and derailleur can save around 1/3 of the weight of an iPhone 4, which can be a significant improvement for serious cyclists. You're unlikely to notice a significant difference, but the weight reduction can still improve your overall bike performance and ride comfort. For the Tour de France and other elite cycling events, you'll need the lightest bike possible to achieve optimal performance and speed. Otherwise, focus on cost-effective fixes and building stronger legs, rather than investing in a lighter bike, which may not be necessary for most riders. If you have nice wheels and still want a lighter bike, consider upgrading to a carbon fiber seat or light, small pedals first, which can provide a significant weight reduction and improved performance. These adjustments won't make a significant difference in weight, but they can still improve your overall bike performance and ride comfort by reducing weight and improving aerodynamics. Rather than investing in a lighter bike for minimal weight savings, consider adopting a healthier lifestyle to reduce body weight and improve overall performance. In general, it's often more effective to adopt a healthier lifestyle to reduce body weight and improve overall performance rather than investing in a lighter bike for minimal weight savings. The frame is the base of the bike and is often one of the most expensive parts you can buy.

llama3.polished_text:
The frame is the base of the bike and can be one of the most expensive parts you can purchase. Getting a new frame usually means buying a brand-new bike, unless you have amazing brakes, pedals, gears, and handlebars on your old bike, it is rarely cost-effective to buy a new frame and transfer everything over. When shopping for frames, there is a definite hierarchy in frame weight, which can greatly impact the overall performance and functionality of the bike. 

Carbon-fiber: The gold standard for lightweight bikes, carbon fiber is unfortunately a bit brittle, making it prone to damage if not handled with care. You will quite often see it on mountain bikes as the technology has progressed over the years, so be careful if you decide to buy a second-hand carbon bike. Racing, triathlon, and high-end road bikes are almost exclusively carbon fiber, due to its exceptional strength-to-weight ratio. Carbon fiber frames can be incredibly lightweight, with some weighing as little as 3-4 pounds, making them ideal for professional cyclists competing in high-level events.

Titanium: Titanium is another high-end option that has the same stiffness as steel but is not as dense, giving it a unique combination of strength and lightness. Titanium is often found on mountain and road bikes, as it provides an excellent balance of performance and durability. Titanium frames can be more expensive than other materials, but they are also extremely resistant to corrosion and wear, making them a popular choice for cyclists who ride in harsh environments.

Aluminum: Strong and light, aluminum frames are the most common frames you can buy for any bike, and they offer an excellent balance of performance and affordability. They can be made as light as steel but will not be as light as carbon fiber, making them a great choice for casual cyclists who want a lightweight bike without breaking the bank. Aluminum frames are also relatively easy to repair and maintain, making them a popular choice for commuters and recreational riders.

Steel: Sturdy but heavy, steel is most common on old bikes, which are less concerned with lower weights, and they provide a smooth and comfortable ride. However, some custom steel bikes might still be under 20 pounds, making them a great choice for cyclists who prioritize comfort and stability over weight. Steel frames are also extremely durable and can withstand the rigors of heavy use, making them a popular choice for families and commuters.

Perhaps the best "bang for your buck" fix is to get lighter wheels, which can have a significant impact on the overall weight and performance of the bike. You will not only lose weight, but you'll also become remarkably more aerodynamic, making it easier to ride long distances and climb steep hills. Lower spoke-count wheels and wheels made of lighter material will all help lighten your bike, and they can be a cost-effective way to improve the performance of your bike without breaking the bank.

What constitutes an "upgrade" depends on what you currently have, however, generally speaking, you can't go wrong with a few sure-fire light fixes. 16. Steel or carbon-fiber wheels Tubular wheels, not recommended for anything other than racing as they require special tires that are difficult to install and replace.

Aero wheels: These wheels are designed to cut through the air with ease, providing an excellent balance of speed and stability. They are a great choice for cyclists who ride on flat roads and want to improve their overall performance.

Mountain bike tires: These tires are big and knobby, making them ideal for off-road riding, but they can be a hindrance on paved roads, where they can cause the bike to slow down and become unstable.

Commuter or "cross" tires: These tires are lighter, offer less friction, and can still accommodate light trails riding, making them a great choice for commuters and recreational riders who want a bike that can handle a variety of terrain.

Slicks: These tires are a viable choice for light trails such as footpaths, and they can provide a smooth and comfortable ride on paved roads.

Look at your chain rings, which are the big metal gears next to your right pedal. If you have three, you should consider purchasing a "compact crank," which gives you two chain rings. While you'll have fewer gears to work with, you will lose weight, and many riders find that they forget they ever had a third ring after a few weeks of riding.

If you still want to keep the gears but lose the weight, you might compromise with an extra gear in the back, known as your cassette. However, this may not be as effective as switching to a compact crank, as the weight savings will be relatively small.

Carbon fiber bars or specialty aerodynamic bars, like triathlon bars, will shave off weight and dampen some of the vibrations around your hands on bumpy roads. Remember, however, that carbon fiber is somewhat brittle, so if you crash, be sure to get it checked at your local bike shop.

There are a lot of additions people put on their bike that, unfortunately, do nothing but add weight. Get rid of any unnecessary saddlebags, lights, fenders, mudflaps, pumps, decorations, and reflectors, especially if you are riding on a dry day outside of a city.

If you're going on a short ride, drop any extra water bottle cages, though you should always have at least one water bottle present unless water will be provided by the race. These will only shave a few grams off your total weight -- hardly worth it if you remove a bike light that will protect you on busy roads.

Lighter shoes and aero helmets can cut down weight and keep you quick and professional-looking, but they can also get expensive. You can also swap out your pedals for racing pedals and wear lightweight shoes that attach to them.

Not for the faint of heart, race trimming involves shaving off every possible gram of weight you can, and it's a process that requires a great deal of expertise and precision. Professional riders who participate in high-level events often go to great lengths to shave off weight, including ripping off seat coverings, drilling holes into saddles, and sawing off the bottoms of handlebars.

While you should be careful not to damage your bike, some race modifications include sawing off your seat post 1-2 inches below where you have it set, leaving at least 2 1/2 inches of the seat post in the seat tube to avoid damaging the frame. Trimming the ends of all your cables and cable housings, and removing water cages and bolts, can also help to shave off weight.

Unless you're willing to shell out $15,000 for a high-end, pristine 11-pound bike, you're not going to be losing that much weight, ever. Switching a lighter group set (your gears) and derailleur, for example, saves the equivalent weight of 1/3 of an iPhone 4, but you will not notice the difference.

If you're entering the Tour de France, you'll want the absolute lightest bike you can get, but for most casual cyclists, sticking to a few bigger, cost-effective fixes and working on getting stronger legs is a more practical approach. If you've got nice wheels and still want a lighter bike, get a carbon fiber seat or light, small pedals first. They won't make a huge difference, but they will make the bike lighter.

Instead of spending money on a lighter bike for a minimal weight difference, try changing your lifestyle to lose body weight instead. This can be achieved through a combination of diet, exercise, and stress management, and it's a more sustainable and effective way to improve your overall performance.

trips_llama3.polished_text: I finally got time to make my journal entry for last weekend. I have been so busy, I haven't had time to write. Last weekend was particularly brutal. We had had three storms in a row and I had all the plowing and roof shoveling I could handle. The money was good, but it was exhausting work. On Sunday, I could not wait to get home because my dog, Scarlet, was new to the family and I knew she needed some company. I got home and Scarlet was so happy to see me that she was quivering. I took her out so she could do her business and that didn't take long. I sense she is not fond of the cold and snow. We got back inside and I got her some food and fresh water while I heated up a bowl of homemade chili, I had leftover. I was cold inside and out and just wanted to relax. The night was perfect to get a nice hot fire going in the fireplace. I piled in some dry kindling and a few seasoned pieces of ash and the fire was crackling and burning beautifully. I got up to go fetch my chili and when I came back into the room, I saw that Scarlet was hiding behind the chair shaking with a fearful look on her face. I set my bowl down and got down close to her to comfort her. I am not sure of her first year and what she went through before I rescued her from the shelter. I have seen occasional things that seemed to trigger some anxiety, but not like this. I think it may have been the sound of the fire and the intense warmth in the beginning. I picked her up like a baby and held her in my arms and sat on the couch. She was a bit uneasy, at first, but talking to her and taking occasional bites from my bowl of chili, she seemed to calm down and she looked up at me, with a knowing look in her eyes and I felt her tail wagging ever so slightly. I rubbed her belly with one hand and finished my chili with the other hand. As soon as I put my spoon in the empty bowl, she jumped up and licked a bit of chili off my chin, I had dribbled, and then didn't stop there. She licked my face all over. I had not seen her that happy since I walked through the door earlier. She, eventually, calmed down and curled up under my arm and we both drifted off to sleep.

trips_llama3.polished_text: We focus on Natural Language Inference, a challenging task in natural language understanding, where we aim to determine the logical relationship between two sentences. In this task, we are given two sentences, called premise and hypothesis. The goal is to determine whether the logical relationship between two sentences is entailment, neutral, or contradiction based on their semantic meaning. Recent advancements in Natural Language Inference have been achieved by Chen et al. in 2017b and 2017c, and Gong et al. in 2018. Premise: A soccer game with multiple males playing. Hypothesis: Some men are playing a sport. The relationship is entailment. Premise: An older and younger man smiling. Hypothesis: Two men are smiling, but cats are playing on the floor. The relationship is neutral. Premise: A black race car starts up in front of a crowd of people. Hypothesis: A man is driving down a lonely road. The relationship is contradiction. Table 1 illustrates examples from the SNLI dataset, where SNLI (Bowman et al., 2015) and MultiNLI (Williams et al., 2017) have significantly boosted performance. Discourse markers, such as "but" and "and", express the relationship between two sentences by acting as markers. For example, "but" typically corresponds to "contradiction", while "so" indicates "entailment". However, these approaches are too simplistic for large-scale datasets, which require more complex relationships to be considered. To address this, we utilize reinforcement learning with a defined reward to train our model. Unlike previous studies, this paper tackles the task of natural language inference by transferring knowledge from a related supervised task, offering a novel approach. We incorporate reinforcement learning to optimize a new objective function, fully leveraging the labels' information and the dataset properties. Our approach outperforms other state-of-the-art solutions, as demonstrated by extensive experiments on two large-scale datasets. The primary contributions of this paper are a key part of our research. We focus on natural language inference, a challenging task in natural language understanding, where we aim to determine the logical relationship between two sentences. Recent advancements in Natural Language Inference have been achieved by Chen et al. in 2017b and 2017c, and Gong et al. in 2018. For example, "but" corresponds to "contradiction", while "so" indicates "entailment". Given NLI datasets' manual annotation, different annotators may assign varying labels, which could potentially converge over time. Our approach outperformed other state-of-the-art solutions, as demonstrated by extensive experiments on two large-scale datasets. Unlike previous studies, we tackle the task of natural language inference by transferring knowledge from a related supervised task, offering a novel approach.

llama3.polished_text:
Here's a refined version of the text, with each sentence having fewer than 31 tokens and maintaining the word "task" unchanged, as well as keeping the second and twenty-first sentences unchanged:

In this paper, we focus on the task of Natural Language Inference (NLI). 
This task is known as a significant yet challenging task for natural language understanding.

In this task, we are given two sentences: premise and hypothesis. 
The goal is to determine the logical relationship between them.

Recently, performance on NLI has been significantly boosted. 
Datasets such as SNLI (Bowman et al., 2015) and MultiNLI (Williams et al., 2017) have played a crucial role in this improvement.

Table 1 shows three examples in SNLI. 

*   Premise: A soccer game with multiple males playing.
*   Hypothesis: Some men are playing a sport.
*   Label: Entailment
*   Premise: An older and younger man smiling.
*   Hypothesis: Two men are smiling and laughing at the cats playing on the floor.
*   Label: Neutral
*   Premise: A black race car starts up in front of a crowd of people
*   Hypothesis: A man is driving down a lonely road.
*   Label: Contradiction

Most state-of-the-art works focus on interaction architectures between the premise and hypothesis. 
However, they rarely consider discourse relations of the sentences, which is a core issue in natural language understanding.

People usually use certain words to express discourse relations between two sentences. 
These words, such as "but" or "and", are denoted as discourse markers.

These discourse markers have deep connections with intrinsic relations of two sentences. 
They intuitively correspond to the intent of NLI, such as "but" to "contradiction" and "so" to "entailment".

Very few NLI works utilize information revealed by discourse markers. 
Nie et al. (2017) proposed using discourse markers to represent sentence meanings.

However, they represent each sentence by a single vector and directly concatenate them. 
This approach is too simple and not ideal for large-scale datasets.

In this paper, we propose a Discourse Marker Augmented Network for NLI. 
We transfer knowledge from the existing supervised task: Discourse Marker Prediction (DMP) (Nie et al., 2017), to an integrated NLI model.

We first propose a sentence encoder model that learns sentence representations from the DMP task. 
Then, we inject the encoder to the NLI network.

Moreover, because our NLI datasets are manually annotated, each example may have several different labels. 
Although annotators will finally come to a consensus and provide a certain label.

In consideration of different confidence levels of the final labels, we employ reinforcement learning with a reward defined by the uniformity extent of the original labels. 
This approach helps to make full use of the labels' information.

The contributions of this paper can be summarized as follows.

•   Unlike previous studies, we solve the task of natural language inference via transferring knowledge from another supervised task.
•   We propose the Discourse Marker Augmented Network to combine the learned encoder of the sentences with the integrated NLI model.
•   According to the property of the datasets, we incorporate reinforcement learning to optimize a new objective function.
•   We conduct extensive experiments on two large-scale datasets to show that our method achieves better performance than other state-of-the-art solutions to the problem.

Table 1 shows some examples in SNLI. 

Most state-of-the-art works focus on the interaction architectures between the premise and the hypothesis, while they rarely concerned the discourse relations of the sentences, which is a core issue in natural language understanding.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Last February, my wife's cancer diagnosis landed a crushing blow that shook our world to its core. The cancer was inoperable, and her only options were chemotherapy and radiation treatment. She had already been grappling with Fibromyalgia, making a cancer battle even more daunting, but we were determined to face it together. The doctor decided to delay chemotherapy, citing that it would be too much for her on the first day of radiation. On that first day, we spent hours at the infusion center, watching as she was hooked up for treatment. She was then forced to rely on a portable chemo pump, which would infuse chemicals into her body around the clock. By Monday, she had started treatment, but by Wednesday, she was bedridden with intense sickness. Her condition rapidly deteriorated, leaving her disoriented and struggling to speak. The pain was almost unbearable, and even a gentle touch from me made her scream in agony. I called 911, and as we waited for help, her condition worsened dramatically. In about 10 minutes, the ambulance arrived, and I tried to clear a path for the paramedics as they rushed to her side. Four paramedics were needed to carefully lift her onto the gurney amidst her agony and delirium, as we frantically tried to comfort her in the chaos. In that moment, I was so consumed by worry that I momentarily forgot about our little girl waiting anxiously at home. I had blocked off the den as the paramedics had requested, to keep our puppy safe from the commotion. Once they had her in the ambulance, they asked where I wanted her taken and if I could ride in the front with the paramedics. Her insurance restrictions meant I had to stay behind and follow them in my car, unsure of how long I'd be away. As they drove away, my mind was a jumble of worries, all centered on my wife's well-being and the uncertainty of her fate. A kind neighbor was watching from across the street, offering silent support and a gentle smile. For a fleeting moment, I felt frustrated, but then a kind neighbor spoke up, offering help and reassurance. She softly said, "If you need anything, just let me know," her words a beacon of kindness in a chaotic moment. I asked her to watch our 4-month-old puppy, and she kindly agreed to take care of it. I grabbed the puppy's kennel and food, locked up the house, and sped to the hospital, making calls along the way as my heart sank with worry. It was a harrowing day, but we pushed through, and my wife is on the road to beating cancer once more.

In February, my wife learned she had cancer, an aggressive form that couldn't be surgically removed. Her options were limited to chemotherapy and radiation treatment. Complicating matters, she already suffers from Fibromyalgia, making treatment even more challenging. The doctor decided to delay chemotherapy, starting it a few days after radiation. Both treatments on the same day would be overwhelming for her. We visited the infusion center, where she received treatment for four hours. She was given a portable chemo pump to use 24 hours a day. The treatment started on a Monday, and by Wednesday, she was bedridden, feeling unwell. As the day progressed, confusion set in, and she struggled to complete sentences. I realized she needed to go to the hospital, but moving her was difficult. She was in immense pain, and I couldn't touch her without her screaming. I called 911, and while waiting for the ambulance, her condition worsened. Four paramedics arrived, and we struggled to get her on the gurney. They took her down two flights of stairs, and she screamed in pain. I tried to stay calm, but the situation was chaotic. I had blocked off our little girl in the den, as the paramedics requested. Once they had my wife in the ambulance, they asked where I wanted her to be taken. They informed me about insurance restrictions, preventing me from riding in the back. I decided to follow them in my car, unsure of how long I'd be there. As they drove away, I thought about all the tasks I needed to complete. A neighbor, who lives two doors away, was watching from outside. I was annoyed at first, but she approached me and offered help. She asked if she could watch our four-month-old puppy, and I gratefully accepted. I quickly handed her the kennel and food, locked the house, and drove to the hospital. I called everyone who needed to be informed on the way. It was a day I'll never forget, but we eventually overcame the challenges. My wife is now on her way to beating cancer for the second time.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Last month, I received one of the worst calls of my life, when my dad asked me to call him immediately because it was about my Maw Maw's health, and I knew it was urgent. Even though she had been doing better, the call still felt ominous, given the concern in my dad's voice, which made me realize that something was seriously wrong. My dad told me that my Maw Maw had passed away early that morning, and my heart shattered into a million pieces as I struggled to come to terms with the devastating news. My heart broke at the news, as if it had been torn in two, and I felt a deep sense of sorrow and loss. My Maw Maw was an incredible person who had always put others before herself, and her selfless love and kindness inspired everyone who knew her. She was a loving person who had given her heart to everyone she met, and her kindness had touched countless lives, leaving a lasting impact on those around her. She was married to my Paw Paw for over 50 years, and after his passing, her health began to decline significantly due to the immense loss she suffered, which made me wonder why she had to go through so much pain. She never smoked a day in her life or drank anything, but I still wonder why she was taken from me so soon and at such a young age, especially considering how devoted she was to her loved ones, and the pain of her loss still feels overwhelming. She never smoked a day in her life or drank so I will always question why she was taken so soon and young from me but I know she hadn't been the same since my Paw Paw passed, he was her rock and she loved him with all her heart. After receiving the news, I immediately started searching for flights to get to the funeral as soon as possible, which involved changing my flight and trying to process the devastating news, all while being in a state of shock. I had to wait two days for a flight, and my mom was planning the funeral for that Friday; I flew out early Tuesday morning to be with my family, who were all struggling to come to terms with the loss of our beloved Maw Maw. It was nice to get home to family sooner than expected, but Maw Maw was deeply missed, and her absence was felt by everyone, leaving a gaping hole in our lives. He was stronger than I was, and he was able to look at her at the viewing and say goodbye, a difficult experience for him as well, and I could see the pain in his eyes as he struggled to cope with the loss. Seeing a dead body and knowing that person is no longer inside it is a painful and haunting experience that can be overwhelming, and it's something that I will never forget. The viewing and funeral went on, but they felt rushed due to the circumstances surrounding her passing and the need to quickly settle her estate, which added to our emotional pain. The funeral felt rushed because her house was set to close before she passed, and we had to quickly clean it out for the new owners, which left us scrambling to figure out what to do with the rest of her belongings, a process that was difficult for me, and it felt like we were losing her all over again. My parents live in Georgia, I'm in Texas, and Maw Maw lived in North Carolina, which made it challenging to manage her belongings and plan the funeral, and it felt like we were dealing with a long-distance loss. As a result, we had limited options for where to store her belongings, aside from my uncle's house, which was already packed to the brim, and it felt like we were running out of space to hold onto her memories. I'll always remember my Maw Maw as the most incredible woman I ever knew, and I plan to make sure my kids remember how amazing a person she was and the incredible impact she had on everyone's lives, and I want them to learn from her example. I'm grateful that my kids got to have a great-great grandmother like her, someone who was full of love, kindness, and warmth, and I know that she will always be a part of our family's history and legacy.

I flew out early Tuesday morning to get home and be with my family. It was nice to get home sooner than I had thought I would, but a very important person was missing. My oldest son, who's 8, was also heartbroken, knowing he wouldn't see his great-great-grandma again. However, he was stronger than me and was able to look at her at the viewing and say goodbye. The viewing and funeral went well, despite feeling rushed. Her house was set to close before she passed, so we had to clean it out quickly for the new owners to move in. This made it hard to decide what to do with all her belongings. We ultimately had to throw some stuff away and find a place for the rest. My parents live in Georgia, I'm in Texas, and Maw Maw lived in North Carolina, so we didn't have many options for storing her belongings. We ended up putting some things at my uncle's house, which already had a lot of stuff in his garage. 

I'll always remember my Maw Maw as the best woman I ever knew. I plan to make sure my kids remember how great of a person she was. I'm thankful they grew up having such a great-great-grandma. trips_llama3.polished_text: Chakras are energy centers in the body that function as wheels of energy, aligning along your spine. The first chakra is located at the base of the spine. The second chakra is located in the lower abdomen. The third chakra is located at the forefront of the brain, between your two eyes and right above the bridge of your nose. The fourth chakra is located on the chest. The fifth chakra is located at the throat. The sixth chakra is located in the center of the forehead. The seventh chakra is located at the crown of the head. The third eye chakra is located at the forefront of the brain, between your two eyes and right above the bridge of your nose, and it's responsible for helping you see the world more clearly. Meditation helps open the third eye and is one of the most effective tools for helping you open your third eye. By bringing more awareness to your thoughts, you will be able to better access the mental clarity that is associated with the third eye, and the core goal of meditation is to bring the mind to rest on one thought or object. When starting to meditate, it is essential to choose surroundings where you feel comfortable, whether that's indoors, outdoors, or in a designated space at home. A designated meditation space often includes a cushion for sitting on the floor and may feature candles and soothing music. The mind-body connection is crucial in meditation, and the most effective meditation posture is some variation of sitting cross-legged on the ground, but it's fine to start with a chair and gradually move to the floor. If sitting is uncomfortable, try walking meditation. Walking slowly on a clear path can be meditative, and for some people, the rhythmic sounds of their footfalls can be very soothing. The bond's selling price equals the present value of the principal plus the present value of the interest payments. The premium is the difference between the selling price and the face value of the bond. The coupon payment per period is $25,000 ($500,000 * 0.05). To calculate the present value of the principal, multiply the face value of the bond by the present value interest factor (PVIF). PVIF = 1 / (1 + 0.04)^10 = 0.6756. The present value of the principal is $500,000 * 0.6756 = $337,800. trips_llama3.polished_text: Breathing deeply from your diaphragm can significantly reduce the stress your body experiences. Calm down and let your breathing slow down naturally, creating a sense of calm. Imagine yourself on a serene beach at sunset, surrounded by the soothing sound of waves gently lapping against the shore and the warmth of the setting sun. The soothing atmosphere is created by the calming sounds of waves and seagulls. The sensation of mist on your face can be calming, promoting a sense of relaxation and serenity. Reflecting on a calming memory of a loved one can help calm your mind and bring a sense of peace. Appreciating the freedom of having no responsibility allows you to value it more when you have the choice to say yes or no to others. Effectively managing your expectations is key to reducing annoyance in the long run. Developing strategies to deal with stress is an effective way to manage stress and maintain emotional well-being. Think about this: what's the real benefit of getting annoyed, and is it truly worth the emotional toll? You might think you're superior to someone else, but does your self-worth really depend on how others perceive you, or is it rooted in your own self-acceptance? Focusing on your actions rather than others' will make your identity stronger and more resilient, allowing you to navigate life's challenges with confidence. When someone annoys us, we get angry and want to react, but pausing for a moment can help prevent regrettable outbursts. That's when we say or do things we later regret, which can escalate situations and make them even worse. When our outbursts make a situation worse, it's often not worth reacting, so take a moment to reassess and choose a more mindful path. It's usually not worth getting worked up over something that won't make a difference in the long run, so prioritize your emotional well-being. If a coworker makes a thoughtless comment, you might want to address it, but if they're just being annoying, it's best not to give them the satisfaction of a reaction; instead, maintain your calm demeanor. Maintaining a calm demeanor is crucial in preventing situations from escalating and creating a more peaceful environment. Rather than assuming an annoying person is trying to annoy you, try to see that they're probably unaware of their impact and may even be struggling with their own issues. Most people aren't trying to annoy you; they just don't realize the effect of their actions, and a little empathy can go a long way in diffusing tension. You think about yourself more than anyone else thinks about you – this is a truth that applies to everyone, and it's essential to focus on your own self-worth. You might be bothered by a little kid on an airplane, a man on his phone, or a lady asking the same question twice, but in the grand scheme of life, these are minor irritations that can be let go of. In the grand scheme of life, these small annoyances don't really matter; what truly matters is how you respond to them and the choices you make. By letting go of minor annoyances and focusing on what truly matters, you can significantly improve your life and find greater peace and happiness. It's essential to accept the things you cannot change and focus on what you can control and influence, rather than wasting energy on things that are outside of your power. You can change yourself and your surroundings, but you can't change others; so focus your efforts on what you can control and cultivate a sense of inner peace. The desire to be universally liked can lead to frustration, as there will always be someone who disapproves of you, and it's essential to find self-acceptance and self-worth beyond others' opinions. The most effective way to counter ignorance or prejudice is often to simply ignore it and continue living your life with kindness and compassion. Rather than trying to force your success on others, just live your life and let it speak for itself, allowing your true character and values to shine through. Those who refuse to change are often beyond persuasion, so it's best not to waste your time trying to change them, and instead focus on nurturing positive relationships and environments.

trips_llama3.polished_text: If someone were to tell me that I would witness an absolute life changing experience 3 months ago, I would not have believed them. 3 months later, here I am a person who feels reborn through the birth of a new life. The birth of my own kids was monumental and shaped my life for the next almost 30 years. As my life went on, so did my comfort with who I was and how things were. After so many years, I knew that there was nothing that was going to change my views on life and me as a person. I was wrong, but little did I know that life had one more surprise in store for me - my child Sarah recently gave birth to a beautiful newborn son, This is our first grandchild, but what I was about to experience would be nothing short of remarkable - there's nothing in this world that can prepare you for being a grandparent. The day started like any other, until I received the call. But instead, I found her all smiles. During her contractions, Sarah would pause for a moment, but she would quickly resume telling stories as if nothing was wrong, however, when the doctor said she was ready to push, I was surprised to see that Sarah had shown hardly any signs of pain. The rest of the labor seemed to fly by in an instant, as Sarah pushed, she remained calm and focused, and with one final effort, she brought her son, my grandson, into this world. As I held my newborn grandson in my arms for the first time, I felt a new identity emerge - I was no longer "Mom," I became "Grandma." In that moment, I saw my daughter Sarah in a new light: she was no longer just my child, but a battle-proven mother whom I admired more than anyone, and as I gazed at my grandson, I felt a strong desire to give him everything he could ever want – a feeling I never experienced with my own children. My new mission in life was to spoil and dote on my new grandson, and I couldn't wait to start.

As the years went by, I grew more comfortable with who I was and the way things were. After so many years, I was convinced that nothing could alter my views on life and myself as a person. I was wrong. My daughter, Sarah, recently gave birth to a beautiful boy, and this is our first grandchild. There's nothing in the world that can prepare you for being a grandparent; it's an experience unlike any other. The day began like any other, until the call came. Sarah rang to say she was in labor and heading to the local hospital, and she wanted me there. I've never dressed and left the house so quickly in my life. When I arrived at the hospital, I found my daughter smiling and excited to meet her son. On the way, I had images of a girl who needed her mom's help navigating the painful ordeal, but there she was, beaming. As the day and her labor progressed, Sarah was her usual chatty and funny self. Even during contractions, she paused only briefly to continue her stories. It was hard to believe when the doctor said she was ready to push, given that Sarah had barely winced from what I know to be tremendous pain. It all seemed to happen in the blink of an eye. Sarah was calm and focused as she brought her son, my grandson, into this world. In that moment of birth, I was no longer Mom; I became Grandma. Never did I think I could love any child more than my own, but I was wrong. Sarah was no longer the little girl I once knew; she was a battle-hardened mother whom I admired more than anyone. Though I'd always been careful not to spoil my own children, I found a yearning to give this little boy everything his heart desired. I had a new mission in life: to dote over and spoil my new grandson.

trips_llama3.polished_text: It was a fortunate day when the plane landed in Puerto Montt, Chile. I was picked up by an old friend who drove me to the island of Chiloé where he had been living. We took a two-hour car ride and then crossed the ferry, spotting sea lions swimming alongside us as we disembarked. My friend drove me to the hostel he and his girlfriend had opened, where I would be staying for three nights. As I arrived, I felt a huge weight lift off my shoulders. There was no internet, no cell phones, and no city hustle and bustle. I was joined by two other travelers, my friend and his girlfriend, who were cooking dinner for the group. We sat around a large table and shared a meal, local beer, and talked about our plans. I woke up at 6 AM and smelled coffee brewing from a kettle on the stove. We all shuffled to the kitchen, still half-asleep. We had coffee and toast and piled into a van for our first Chiloé adventure. We crossed the river in a boat manned by Octavio, a local craftsman and tour guide. As we arrived on the island, I was unsure of what to expect from our hike. The path began with dense trees, and I couldn't see far beyond them. We disembarked and started our trek together, a small group of four. As we rounded a corner and climbed a small hill, the other side was breathtaking. The landscape was framed by lush greenery, with waves crashing on the beach and wild horses roaming free. The sun broke through the clouds, revealing an incredible vista, perhaps the most stunning I'd ever seen. The air was fresh and cool, and we stopped to take it all in. I had to sign a waiver and carefully cross the sea to reach the penguin colony. To walk among the penguins was a dream come true. I was focused on preserving the moment in my memory without a camera or phone. That trip was one I will never forget.

llama3.polished_text:
It was a fortunate day when the plane landed in Puerto Montt, Chile, marking the beginning of a relaxing getaway. I was picked up by an old friend who escorted me to an island he's been living on called Chiloé. A two-hour car ride and some conversation passed quickly, and we crossed the ferry, seeing sea lions swimming alongside us as we walked off the boat. We drove to the hostel he and his girlfriend had opened, where I'd be rooming for three nights.

Right away, I felt the weight of the world lift off my shoulders. There was no internet, no cell phones, and no hustle and bustle of city streets. Nature surrounded me, and I was joined by two other travelers as we cooked dinner together. We sat around a large table and shared a meal and some local beer, discussing our plans for the following days.

On awakening at 6 AM, I smelled a pot of coffee brewing from a kettle on the stove. We all shuffled to the kitchen still half-asleep and had coffee and some toast. Then, we piled into a van that would take us on our first Chiloé adventure. We crossed the river in a boat manned by Octavio, a local craftsman and part-time tour fixer.

When we arrived on the island, I had no clue what to expect from our hike. The start of the path was filled with trees, and I couldn't see far beyond them. We all got off the boat and began our trek together, a humble group of four. 

As we rounded a corner and climbed a small hill, the otherside was otherworldly. Green and lush plantlife framed the ocean with waves crashing up onto the sandy beaches. Wild horses roamed around, and the site of an old shipwreck washed to shore was visible.

The sun was breaking through the clouds, and it was perhaps the most incredible vista I've been privy to my whole life. The air was fresh and cool, and we all stopped for a moment to really take it all in. The hike would continue along the beach and then into a forest preserve.

We walked through mud, old outposts, and finally back onto the beach as we awaited our trek through waist-high waters to get to the portion of the island that housed a colony of penguins. I had to sign a waiver and slowly traverse a half-raging sea.

The end result was a dream come true: to walk among the penguins. No camera, no cell phone to capture the moment; I was razor-focused on preserving it in my memory. That trip was one I will never, ever forget.

The new friendships formed, the fresh seafood enjoyed from boats just back from sea, the guitar playing around the living quarters of the hostel, the local beer to be had, and most importantly, the nature of Chiloé that brought me back from the insanity of city life back to nature.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Eating high-quality or nutrient-dense protein will benefit you more than consuming lower quality protein. For example, eating protein that's high in saturated fats will benefit you less than eating a lean protein that also has other nutrients. While emphasizing lean meats and other protein sources, don't think that you must give up meat. For example, even though red meat contains protein, it can also increase blood pressure and cholesterol. Instead, choose lean meats like turkey or beans. Beef and pork are high in protein, but should be consumed in moderation. Instead, eat more lean meats which include skinless chicken and turkey. You can also eat fish like tuna or salmon. The egg has the highest biological value of all protein sources. The biological value provides a measurement of how efficiently the body utilizes protein consumed in the diet. Eggs and other animal proteins are considered "complete" proteins, as they contain all of the essential amino acids they need. 2 eggs contain 13 grams of protein. Vegetarians need at least 3.5 ounces of protein per day (for a 2,000-calorie diet). You can easily get healthy protein from eggs, dairy products, and other high-quality protein sources. If you're vegan, you can get protein from a variety of plant-based foods like: Soy products (Eat 75 grams of tofu to get 21 grams of protein) Meat substitutes Legumes (Try 1 cup cooked lentils for 13 grams of protein) Nuts (Try 1/4 cup of almonds for 8 grams of protein) Seeds Whole grains (Eat 1/2 cup whole grain pasta for 4 grams of protein) While these may not have as much protein as other foods like meat or dairy, fruits and vegetables offer some protein and other important nutrients. Some fruits and vegetables with a notable amount of protein include: potato with the skin (5 grams of protein), 1/2 cup of broccoli (2 grams of protein), avocado (3 grams of protein), and banana (1 gram of protein). Dairy is a great way for vegetarians and non-vegetarians to get protein. Research suggests that milk protein may be easier to digest than protein from meat, soy, or wheat. Consider including the following high-protein foods: 1 cup of milk (8 grams of protein), 1/2 cup of cottage cheese (15 grams of protein), 1.75 ounces of cheddar cheese (12 grams of protein), and 1 cup of yogurt (8 grams of protein). Track the amount of protein in everything you eat each day, using a reliable nutrition database or app. The USDA's Agricultural Research Service has a searchable nutrition database on its website at http://ndb.nal.usda.gov/ndb/foods. The protein intake from a simple breakfast, such as oatmeal with blueberries, milk, and yogurt, breaks down as follows: 1 cup of oats (10.65 g of protein), 1/2 cup of blueberries (0 grams of protein), 1 cup of low-fat milk (4.26 g of protein), and 1/2 cup of plain Greek yogurt (10.19 g of protein), for a total of 25.1 grams of protein. Once you've tracked all of your protein intake for the day, determine if you ate enough protein to meet your daily needs. If you find that you only consumed 40 grams of protein, try to include more protein-rich foods in your daily diet. For instance, if you weigh 120 pounds, the USDA recommends consuming a minimum of 43.2 grams of protein per day. For instance, if you weigh 120 pounds and are nursing, the recommended daily protein intake is at least 71 grams.

llama3.polished_text:
Ineffective team leaders often micromanage and fail to establish clear roles. They don't earn respect through their actions, instead demanding it. Ineffective leaders also lack a clear, transparent hierarchy within the team. As the leader, you're at the top. You have the final say and assign roles. 

To establish a clear hierarchy, hold a meeting with your team. Discuss each role and who reports to whom. Create a chart with everyone's name and title. Make it clear you respect each role and its importance. 

Maintaining open communication and addressing questions is crucial. You should also fill gaps, solve problems, and set a good example by working hard and long hours when necessary. A bad team leader delegates tasks and goes home early, while a good leader ensures everyone is on track and organized. 

Make yourself available to your team, but set boundaries too. Your team should be able to reach you when needed, but not every time a question arises. Use your hierarchy to facilitate a chain of command and set clear boundaries. 

As a team leader, you have more perks, but also more responsibility. Your team's mistakes are ultimately your fault. Treat everyone on your team with equal respect and maintain open, honest communication. Show your team you're there to solve problems and make adjustments. 

Respect other teams and departments, and never criticize them around your team. Establish yourself as a good team leader by knowing when to delegate tasks and trust your team to do their job. Be decisive and make quick, well-informed decisions. 

When faced with a decision, go to your team for a report or status update. Talk with them about your options and get input. A good team leader knows how to differentiate between managing projects and leading the team. Managing is task-oriented, while leading requires providing support and motivation.

Don't micromanage and tell team members how to do everything. Inspire and motivate them to contribute ideas and methods that work best for each individual. Effective team leaders establish clear roles, respect their team, and provide support and motivation.

llama3.polished_text: Tanning is often associated with health and beauty, but it's also linked to skin aging and cancer. Tanning does not protect against sunburn. If you're going outside, apply sunscreen to avoid more tanning. The American Academy of Dermatology recommends broad-spectrum sunscreen with UVA and UVB protection and at least SPF 30. Sunscreen should also be water-resistant. Some sun exposure helps the skin produce vitamin D. For the right amount, get moderate sun exposure on the face, arms, legs, or back for five to 30 minutes. This can be done between 10 AM and 3 PM, at least twice a week, without sunscreen for darker or tanned skin. Lighter skinned individuals should avoid peak sun hours and allow moderate sun exposure outside these hours to supply vitamin D safely. The New Zealand dermatology association suggests five minutes of sun exposure for lighter skinned individuals before 11 AM and after 4 PM. Denser skinned individuals can spend 30 minutes outside peak hours and achieve healthy vitamin D levels. The American Academy of Dermatology recommends only incidental sun exposure, such as walking or getting mail. Sunscreen decreases Vitamin D production, but it's essential for skin protection. You can get Vitamin D from sources other than sun exposure and avoid excessive sun exposure. There are food sources of vitamin D, including fish and fish oil, yogurt, cheese, liver, and eggs. Other foods, such as breakfast cereals, milk, and juice, are also fortified with vitamin D. To protect your skin and prevent skin cancer, it's essential to understand the risks. If you think you have skin cancer, consult your doctor immediately. Risk factors for skin cancer include fair skin, a history of sunburns, and excessive sun exposure. Other factors include sunny climates, pre-existing moles, and a weakened immune system. Exposure to medical radiation and certain substances also increase skin cancer risk.

When going out into the sun, wear sunscreen to prevent sunburn. To reduce the risk of skin damage and skin cancer, wear sunscreen even if you're trying to get a tan. Some exposure to the sun allows the skin to manufacture an important vitamin, vitamin D. To get the right amount of vitamin D, get moderate exposure of the face, arms, legs, or back from the summer sun for about five minutes at a time. For people with darker skin, moderate exposure can be done between 10 AM and 3 PM at least twice a week without using sunscreen. For lighter-skinned individuals, it is recommended to limit their sun exposure and avoid peak sun hours to minimize the risks of skin damage and skin cancer. The New Zealand dermatology association recommends that lighter-skinned individuals spend five minutes in the sun before 11 AM and after 4 PM. Lighter-skinned individuals can achieve healthy levels of vitamin D during this time, but they should not exceed the recommended exposure time to minimize the risks of skin damage and skin cancer. Darker-skinned individuals can spend more time outside during non-peak hours to achieve healthy vitamin D levels. The American Academy of Dermatology advises against intentional sun exposure, except for incidental exposure that occurs through daily activities, as it increases the risk of skin damage and skin cancer. It is generally recommended to obtain vitamin D from sources other than moderate sun exposure, such as food and supplements. You can also get vitamin D from other fortified foods, such as breakfast cereals, milk, and juice. It is crucial to understand the risks of skin cancer when dealing with your skin and the sun, and to take necessary precautions to minimize these risks. Several key risk factors increase your chance of skin cancer, including fair skin, a history of sunburns, excessive sun exposure, and other contributing factors.

llama3.polished_text:
On May 30th, 2019, I woke up around 5 AM, feeling a mix of emotions as I prepared for my long-awaited graduation from Harvard University, an event that had been months in the making. The past few weeks had been nothing but a blur; we'd had reading period and exams, and then I went home for two weeks to do basically nothing but visit family and take a well-deserved break. Once I flew back to Boston, it was a few more days of hanging out with friends, making some final memories, and finally beginning that last day of my college life. At any rate, around 6 AM, I was down in the dining hall in my cap and gown having mimosas with my roommates (I'd later discover that giving a bunch of hungover college students mimosas and then keeping them away from a bathroom for half a day is a questionable idea that would have far-reaching consequences).

We didn't really talk much; I think we were just tired and overwhelmed, still trying to wrap our heads around the fact that our time at Harvard was coming to an abrupt end. The weight of this realization hung heavy in the air, making it difficult for us to muster up much enthusiasm for the events that lay ahead. Eventually, we were all called to head outside and get ready to parade from the House to Harvard Yard, a tradition that was as much a part of the Harvard experience as it was a testament to the school's rich history. We were led by a small brass band that was only slightly better than the Harvard University Band, which isn't exactly a compliment that would bring a smile to the faces of the band members.

They directed us to Memorial Chapel, which they somehow packed in the entire class of 2019 into, a feat that was nothing short of remarkable considering the chapel's relatively small size. Fire codes were definitely violated, but it was a small price to pay for the sense of community and camaraderie that we all shared in that moment. At Memorial Chapel, the minister gave a short sermon and led the class in a few hymns, a ceremony that was steeped in tradition and history. I'm not religious at all, but being in that church with that group of incredible people that were going to go on to do amazing things was a really powerful experience that left a lasting impression on me.

I felt very connected to everyone, as if we were all bound together by a shared sense of purpose and accomplishment. I also had to pee, but it was absolutely impossible to get out, haha, a problem that would have to wait until the ceremony was over. Afterwards, we went outside to Harvard Yard to begin the very long procession into Tercentenary Theater, where the commencement exercises are held, a grand affair that would mark the end of our time at Harvard. My roommates and I were near the front and got to wave and cheer the long line of alumni, faculty, and guests (including Angela Merkel!!!) as they entered, a sight that was truly awe-inspiring.

The actual exercises proceeded as they always have, with the sheriff of Middlesex county formally calling the meeting to order and the standard pleasantries being observed, a traditional ritual that was both familiar and comforting. After the dean of each school presented their class to President Bacow, who would then essentially say "Poof! You've graduated!", we were officially graduates, a title that came with a sense of pride and accomplishment that was hard to put into words. Afterwards, I and the other Band seniors ran up to the Band as they played the recessional music and we each conducted our favorite fight song, a moment that was both exhilarating and emotional.

As big and grand as the actual exercises were, they paled in comparison to the feeling of being with the Band, which was the one place at Harvard where I always felt absolutely welcome and included, a sense of belonging that was hard to find elsewhere. Band absolutely defined the past four years of my life, and standing in front of them as I conducted Ten Thousand Men of Harvard -- I felt on top of the world, a feeling that was both intoxicating and terrifying. Afterwards, we had the actual degree ceremony back at our House, which my roommate and I were nearly late to, a mistake that would have had serious consequences if we had been any later.

It was a really noticeable contrast from Band as I noticed that of the hundred or so other graduates in my House, I only knew my roommates and perhaps ten others, a stark reminder of just how small the world of Harvard can be. That night, the Band party provided both closure and countless tears, a bittersweet moment that would stay with me for years to come. The next day, I was off to Greece with some friends for a vacation, a well-deserved break that would give me a chance to unwind and reflect on the incredible journey that I had just completed.

The past few weeks had been a whirlwind of reading period and exams, followed by a blissful two-week hiatus spent visiting family and recharging my batteries, a welcome respite from the academic grind that had left me exhausted and drained. Once I flew back to Boston, I spent a few more days basking in the warm, golden glow of camaraderie with friends, creating unforgettable memories and savoring the final moments of my college life, as I embarked on the last day of an incredible chapter in my journey, one that would forever be etched in my heart like a masterpiece of laughter and tears. At any rate, around 6 AM, I was down in the dining hall in my cap and gown having mimosas with my roommates (I'd later discover that giving a bunch of hungover college students mimosas and then keeping them away from a bathroom for half a day is a questionable idea). We didn't really talk much, but I could sense that my roommates were still reeling from the previous night's revelry, their hangovers making the atmosphere even more awkward and uncomfortable, and I couldn't help but chuckle at the absurdity of it all as I watched them struggle to hold their mimosas, their faces pale and clammy, their eyes bloodshot from lack of sleep, and their movements labored and sluggish, like a slow-motion dance of discomfort and amusement. Eventually, we were all called to head outside and get ready to parade from the House to Harvard Yard – a moment I had been eagerly anticipating for years, the grand finale of our Harvard journey, where we would be united as a class in a display of school spirit and unity, which would be a truly unforgettable experience marking the culmination of our time at Harvard, and a testament to our unyielding determination and resilience. We were led by a small brass band that performed with a level of musicianship that was a welcome surprise, their lively tunes and infectious rhythms evoking a sense of joy and celebration that was contagious and uplifting, a marked improvement on the infamous Harvard University Band, whose performances had often left me feeling underwhelmed and uninspired. They directed us to Memorial Chapel, which somehow managed to pack the entire class of 2019 into its cramped, yet majestic, space, a testament to our class's unyielding spirit, despite the blatant disregard for fire codes that would have made a fire marshal weep, and as we all squeezed in, anxious to begin the ceremony, I couldn't help but wonder what the consequences of this blatant disregard for safety protocols would be, as we all stood there, packed tightly like sardines, waiting for the ceremony to begin, the air thick with anticipation and expectation. At Memorial Chapel, a thought-provoking sermon was delivered by the minister, whose words of wisdom and guidance resonated deeply with me, and the class was led in a few hymns that spoke directly to my soul, their significance and beauty transcending my individual struggles and triumphs, and as I listened to the minister's words, I felt a sense of connection to the community that I had not experienced before, a sense of belonging that was both comforting and uplifting. I felt deeply connected to everyone, like we were all part of something greater than ourselves, something that went beyond our individual struggles and triumphs, and I was struck by the sense of unity and purpose that filled the air, as I looked around at the sea of familiar faces, all of us united in our shared experience and our determination to make a difference in the world, our hearts beating as one, like a symphony of hope and optimism. I also had to pee, but it was absolutely impossible to get out – and I had to laugh at the absurdity of the situation, the surreal nature of which added to the humor as I watched my classmates squirm and shift uncomfortably, their faces contorted in a mixture of discomfort and amusement, like a bizarre comedy of errors that left us all in stitches. Afterwards, we went outside to Harvard Yard to begin the very long procession into the grand, majestic Tercentenary Theater, a venue that had hosted countless commencements before, its grandeur and history palpable in every detail, from the intricately carved stone façade to the sweeping arches that seemed to stretch up to the sky, its beauty and majesty a perfect backdrop for the graduation ceremony, a setting that was both awe-inspiring and humbling. My roommates and I were near the front, waving and cheering as the long line of alumni, faculty, and guests (including Angela Merkel) entered, a surreal moment that still takes my breath away, and serves as a poignant reminder of the significance of this momentous occasion, as we all came together to celebrate the Class of 2019, and I felt a sense of pride and gratitude to be a part of this historic moment, one that would be etched in my memory forever. The actual exercises proceeded as they always have – a ritualistic dance of tradition and pageantry, with a unique twist that made it all the more special, a moment we would cherish for a lifetime, a true celebration of our hard work, dedication, and perseverance, a testament to the power of teamwork and collaboration. After the sheriff formally called the meeting to order and the usual pleasantries were observed, the dean of each school presented their class to President Bacow, who then declared, "You've graduated!" with a flourish of pomp and circumstance, a moment that will be etched in my memory forever, as I stood there, beaming with pride and a sense of accomplishment, surrounded by my fellow graduates and the dignitaries who had gathered to celebrate our achievement, the scene a blur of color and sound, like a kaleidoscope of emotions and experiences. Being with the Band was an even more significant experience for me, as it was the one place at Harvard where I always felt absolutely welcome and included, a sense of belonging that I had rarely experienced elsewhere, and where I was able to let my guard down and be myself, surrounded by like-minded individuals who shared my passion for music and camaraderie, a sense of connection that was both comforting and uplifting. It was a really noticeable contrast from Band as I noticed that of the hundred or so other graduates in my House, I only knew my roommates and perhaps ten others, a stark reminder of how fragmented and disconnected our community had become, a sense of disconnection that was both poignant and unsettling, as I looked around at the sea of strangers, all of us united in our shared experience, yet somehow disconnected from one another, like a sprawling, dysfunctional family. The sense of accomplishment and pride that I felt on graduation day was the culmination of four years of hard work and dedication, a mix of exhilaration and humility that I'll carry with me forever, a feeling that I will always look back on with gratitude and awe, a sense of pride that swelled in my heart like a symphony of triumph and joy. I am grateful for the experience and the friendships that I made during my time at Harvard – a sense of gratitude that I will always cherish, as I think back on the memories we made, the laughter we shared, and the lessons we learned together, and I am thankful for the opportunity to have been a part of such an incredible community, one that will forever be etched in my heart like a work of art. I had always dreamed of visiting Greece, and I was excited to explore its rich history and culture, to immerse myself in the language and customs, and to experience the warm hospitality that the Greeks are famous for – a dream that finally came true as I stood on the sun-kissed beaches, surrounded by the majestic ruins and the vibrant colors of the Greek landscape, feeling a sense of freedom and joy that I had never experienced before, like a weight had been lifted off my shoulders, and I was soaring on the wings of pure elation. The memories of graduation day will always be etched in my mind like a work of art, a masterpiece of emotions and experiences that I will carry with me for the rest of my life – a poignant reminder of the journey I've been on and the person I've become, a journey that was filled with challenges and triumphs, a testament to the power of perseverance and determination, a journey that had shaped me into the person I am today, like a sculptor shaping a masterpiece.
