To pierce yourself safely, choose a clean area with a flat space and a counter. A bathroom is ideal. Ensure the area is easy to sterilize and clean up any blood spills. First, mix 1 part bleach with four parts water as a cleaning solution. Clean the bathroom thoroughly, focusing on areas you'll touch during the procedure. Scrub the counter and any other surfaces that may come into contact with the needle. 

Cleanliness is crucial for safety. If you bought sterile clamps and jewelry, boil them in water, then wipe them down with your bleach solution. It's a good idea to sterilize them regardless, as you don't know what they may have come into contact with. Once everything is clean, put on gloves and lay out your supplies: a sterile needle, clamps, jewelry, alcohol wipes, a marker, and A&D ointment. 

Remove your gloves and dispose of them. Put on a fresh pair of clean rubber gloves. Clean the area where you want to pierce yourself with an alcohol wipe. Mark two dots, one for the needle's entry and one for its exit, using a marker. Ensure the dots are a suitable distance apart for your jewelry. Visualize the piercing with jewelry in place. Double-check that the marks are straight and in the correct position. 

Keep in mind that marking the dots does not guarantee the jewelry will be in the same position. You may shift the needle due to pain, resulting in a crooked piercing. This is a good reason to have someone else do it for you. Put on a fresh pair of gloves and take your clamps (if you have them). Stretch the skin and align the dots on either side of the clamps. Gently close the clamps on the skin, ensuring each dot is centered and a straight line could pass through both. This method is better suited for certain types of penis piercings. For PA's, use a different method, as they are harder to do and should be done professionally.

llama3.polished_text:
I had to get up the student teaching position. I was so excited to have it. 
I was in the classroom for the past few weeks, enjoying it. My son was having issues at school. The school recommended half days for him. 
I could only student teach for half a day. My college was okay with this. But I realized I wasn't. 
I was only there until 10:40, not long enough to learn. It was a hard decision. Not only did I have to give up teaching, but I had to drop out of college too. 
I never imagined being a college dropout for even a semester. I was excited to get into graduate school. 
To make things worse, I had to pay 10% of my bill since I dropped out. This is a couple of hundred dollars I don't have. 
I'll have to pay this back before I can apply to go back in January. This is still up in the air because my son's full-time status is uncertain. 
This situation has been weighing heavily on my heart. I stayed home with my children for so long. I was excited to finally find myself and my future career. 
The only thing that makes this easier is that my son is doing much better in school. It's hard to give up something you were excited about. Seeing the reason you gave it up flourish makes it easier. 
I'm planning on doing other things while I wait to get back to school. I'm applying to teach online to kids in China. This will keep me prepared for student teaching. 
Something is better than nothing. I just have to keep reminding myself that I got this.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Maintaining a healthy diet is crucial for pregnant teenagers, providing the necessary nutrients for growth and development. A well-balanced diet that includes whole grains, fruits, vegetables, and lean protein sources is vital for a healthy pregnancy and overall well-being. Government programs like WIC can help pregnant women afford nutritious food, ensuring they and their babies receive the necessary nutrients for healthy development. Drinking enough fluids throughout the day is vital for staying hydrated and supporting fetal growth. If you experience an eating disorder during pregnancy, seek help from a registered dietitian or therapist to develop a healthy relationship with food and your body. Poor nutrition during pregnancy can put you and your baby at risk for serious health complications, including premature birth and low birth weight. Teaching your family about good nutrition by preparing healthy meals together can model healthy eating habits and promote a positive relationship with food. As a pregnant student, it's essential to plan meals that support your health and well-being, considering your dietary needs and restrictions. Substances like drugs, alcohol, and junk food can harm you and your child, leading to serious health problems. Quitting these substances as soon as possible can greatly reduce your risk of health problems and improve your mood and energy levels. If you're struggling with addiction, talk to your school nurse, counselor, or doctor for support and resources to overcome your addiction. As a pregnant student, managing your energy levels and getting enough rest can be challenging, requiring you to adjust your sleep schedule and take naps when needed. If you need to take a nap, ask your school about a quiet space or nap area where you can rest without disrupting classes. Regular exercise can help pregnant women sleep better, reduce health risks, and ease back pain, making it essential to incorporate physical activity into their daily routine. If you're new to exercise, start with short walks or low-impact activities like yoga or Pilates to build stamina and endurance. During pregnancy, it's essential to avoid lying on your back after the first trimester to prevent discomfort and pressure on your back and joints. Staying hydrated while exercising is crucial; drink plenty of fluids before, during, and after your workout to prevent dehydration. If you're looking for a low-impact exercise class, check with your local hospital, fitness center, or gym for prenatal yoga or other classes designed for expectant mothers. As a pregnant student, school becomes more of a job and less of a social space, requiring you to prioritize tasks, set realistic goals, and manage your time effectively. To stay organized, keep a calendar with all your assignments, doctor's appointments, and other important dates to meet deadlines and appointments. When it comes to sex during pregnancy, discuss your options and any concerns with your doctor, who can provide guidance and support. Practicing safe sex is essential during pregnancy to prevent sexually transmitted infections that can cause serious health problems in newborns. If you're in college and struggling to balance your pregnancy with your academic responsibilities, consider taking a semester off to focus on your health and your baby's well-being. Talk to your guidance counselor about leaving and returning to school, as they can help you explore your options and make an informed decision about your academic future. If you take time off, you may be eligible for extra scholarships for students who are parents when you return to school, which can help cover the costs of tuition and other expenses. If you're in high school and struggling to balance your pregnancy with your schoolwork, consider taking classes for your GED, which can help you earn your high school equivalency certificate and prepare for college or other post-secondary education.

llama3.polished_text: Many people find the decision to stop cutting first comes from within. Before reaching out to another person, it may be helpful to think about why you need and want to change your behavior. People have different motivations for quitting. You may be motivated by a desire to manage your pain better. You may be fearful of the behavior getting worse, or getting sent to the hospital. You may also worry about how your cutting affects friends and loved ones. Whatever your reasons, identify why you want to quit. Starting a journal to write down how you are feeling when you want to cut can help understand how to stop or find other coping methods. It can even help to write down a list of reasons that you do not want to cut anymore. You can refer back to this list in moments when you feel tempted. It is very hard to stop cutting on your own. It can be helpful to open up to someone when you begin the quitting process. This person can provide you with support along the way. Choose someone you know you can trust. You do not want to pick a friend who's notorious for gossip or someone who is judgmental. It may be a good idea to tell a parent, as your mom or dad can help you find professional help. It can be scary to admit to someone you have been cutting. You may be afraid of an adverse reaction. Keep in mind, however, you will probably feel relieved once you tell someone. It's very hard to keep things bottled up, and you will feel better once you've reached out and asked for support. Consider speaking with your pediatrician or family doctor as a first step. They can be a very helpful resource. It may be easier to tell your parents, too, if you have already talked about it with your doctor and you, your parents, and your doctor can discuss it together. Your comfort is very important. Telling someone you have been cutting is not easy, and it's essential you open up in a way that makes you feel safe. You do not have to have a face-to-face conversation right away. If the idea of telling someone directly is scary, try writing a letter or email. Allow the person to process, and then talk face-to-face later on. You don't have to share everything. If you're not ready to open up about some information, give yourself time. Make it clear to the person you may not answer all the questions they have. You do not have to show your injuries or explain any details you're not ready to share. Focus on your feelings when you talk to the other person. Do not talk primarily about the self-harm behavior. Talk about the feelings, situations, or emotions that led to the behavior. For example, "I've been so stressed about school. I think I'm having trouble managing my emotions about my senior year." It can be shocking to hear a loved one is cutting. The person you open up to may need time to process the information. Have some patience. You may dislike someone's initial reaction. Remember, reactions are usually temporary. Just because someone responds with shock, fear, or anger does not mean they will feel this way forever. These reactions usually come out of concern for you. It can help to print out some pamphlets about cutting that you find online. Many people do not understand self-harm. Having some reading material can help them process. If you have already reached out for help from a health professional, such as your family doctor or a counselor at school, it may be helpful for you and your parents to meet with them so they can support you as you tell your parents. It's great to have someone to support you as you quit. However, a friend, family member, or loved one may not be able to help you during a crisis. In some situations, psychiatric or medical help is necessary. If you ever feel suicidal, call 9-1-1. You can also call the National Suicide Prevention Hotline at (800) 273-8255. If you find yourself in crisis without anyone to talk to, call (800) 366-8288. This is the number for the S.A.F.E Alternatives program, which offers support for those who engage in self-harm. The S.A.F.E Alternatives program is a great resource for those in crisis. They can provide you with support and guidance. The program's hotline is available 24/7. You can talk to a trained counselor and get the help you need. Many people have found the program to be very helpful. It's not a substitute for professional help, but it can be a good starting point. If you have already talked to a professional, it's still worth calling the S.A.F.E Alternatives hotline. They can provide you with additional support and resources. You can also ask to speak with a counselor who specializes in self-harm. They can offer you guidance and support. It's essential to be honest with yourself about why you want to quit cutting. You may need to confront some difficult emotions. It's okay to take things one step at a time. You don't have to do it all alone. If you're not ready to quit, that's okay too. Just being aware of your behavior and the reasons behind it can be a good first step. You can start by talking to a professional about your feelings. They can help you develop a plan to quit cutting. It may take time, but you can do it. Many people have successfully quit cutting and gone on to live happy, healthy lives.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Writing mathematical proofs has been identified as an essential component of computing education, serving as a critical skill for students to master, while also presenting a significant challenge for educators to effectively teach and assess, requiring a substantial investment of time and resources to provide students with timely and constructive feedback, which is crucial for their learning and growth. A large body of research has consistently shown that timely and constructive feedback is critical to student learning, enabling them to refine their understanding, address misconceptions, and develop a deeper understanding of mathematical concepts, as indicated by numerous studies that have demonstrated the positive impact of feedback on student outcomes. However, students often face significant challenges in receiving timely feedback on written proofs due to the time-consuming nature of grading by instructors or teaching assistants, resulting in delayed feedback, hindering the learning process, and placing a substantial burden on educators who must dedicate considerable time to grading and providing feedback. The ability to grade student proofs fully automatically with natural language processing (NLP) alleviates this need by allowing educators to provide students with instant feedback on their proofs, enabling them to iteratively enhance the quality of their work, develop a deeper understanding of mathematical concepts, and improve their problem-solving skills, which significantly benefits students. In this paper, we propose a novel set of training methods and models capable of autograding freeform mathematical proofs by leveraging existing NLP models and other machine learning techniques, which evaluates the quality of student submissions and provides a more accurate and efficient way to assess student work. Our proof autograder enables the development of grading systems that provide instant feedback to students without requiring attention from instructors, thereby enhancing the learning experience and promoting a more efficient and effective educational process, allowing educators to focus on providing guidance and support to students, who can then make the most of their learning experience. The main contributions of this paper are: • Introducing the first pipeline of machine learning models capable of autograding mathematical proofs with accuracy similar to human graders • Quantifying the amount of training data needed to achieve satisfactory performance from the grading models • Publishing an anonymized and labeled mathematical proof dataset that can be used in future model developments • Creating a set of autograded problems using the grading pipeline, and performing a user study that answers the following research questions: – Are students able to write better proofs by interacting with the autograder and the feedback it generates? – Are students satisfied with the autograder and the feedback it provides? – Does using the autograder make students more willing to use similar AI autograders in the future? Our proof autograder is designed to provide students with instant feedback on their mathematical proofs, allowing them to improve their skills and knowledge in a more efficient and effective manner, leveraging the capabilities of machine learning and natural language processing to create a more personalized and adaptive learning experience, which is beneficial for students. The autograder uses a range of machine learning models and natural language processing techniques to evaluate the quality of students' proofs, providing a more accurate and efficient way to assess student work, and enabling educators to focus on providing guidance and support to students, who can then make the most of their learning experience. We believe that the use of our proof autograder can lead to significant improvements in student learning outcomes and increased student satisfaction with the educational experience, as students are able to receive instant feedback and guidance, and educators are able to provide targeted support and interventions, which is beneficial for both parties.

llama3.polished_text: Writing mathematical proofs has been identified as an essential yet challenging topic in computing education and mathematics education, requiring significant attention and resources from instructors and institutions. A substantial body of research has consistently shown that timely and constructive feedback is crucial to student learning, as it enables them to understand their mistakes, identify knowledge gaps, and develop a deeper understanding of mathematical concepts. However, students are largely unable to receive timely feedback on their written proofs due to the need for instructors or teaching assistants to collect and hand-grade the proofs. The inability to provide instant feedback on mathematical proofs hinders student progress and limits their ability to develop high-quality proof skills. The ability to grade student proofs fully automatically with natural language processing (NLP) alleviates this need by allowing us to give students instant feedback on their proofs, enabling them to iteratively enhance the quality of their proofs and develop a more nuanced understanding of mathematical concepts. In this paper, we propose a novel set of training methods and models capable of autograding freeform mathematical proofs, a problem at the intersection of mathematical proof education and Automatic Short Answer Grading (ASAG), by leveraging existing NLP models and other machine learning techniques. Our proof autograder enables the development of grading systems that provide instant feedback to students without requiring attention from instructors, thereby streamlining the grading process and increasing student engagement. It can also be deployed in large-scale educational platforms, allowing for more equitable access to quality education for students. The main contributions of this paper are: • Introducing the first pipeline of machine learning models capable of autograding mathematical proofs with similar accuracy to human graders • Quantifying the amount of training data needed to achieve a satisfactory performance from the grading models • Publishing an anonymized and labeled mathematical proof dataset that can be used in future model developments • Creating a set of autograded problems using the grading pipeline, and performing a user study that answers the following research questions: – Are students able to write better proofs by interacting with the autograder and the feedback it generates? – Are students satisfied with the autograder and the feedback it provides? – Does using the autograder make students more willing to use similar AI autograders in the future? The rest of the paper is organized as follows: we first introduce the related work in Section 2, and then present the source and preprocessing of the training data for our model in 3.1. We then introduce the large language models used in the grading process and our own model for grade calculation in Sections 3.2 and 3.3. Section 3.4 gives the methods for the comparison to human graders. In Section 4, we show the performances from each large language model on the data, and compare the model grading against human grader performances. In Sections 5 and 6, we provide detailed information about a user study where we recruited students to write and improve their proofs using the developed autograders, and collected their progress and feedback with the autograder. The findings from this study provide valuable insights into the effectiveness of our proof autograder and its potential to improve student learning outcomes in mathematics education.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Language models have become one of the most dominant components in many natural language processing (NLP) applications due to their remarkable performance in mainstream NLP tasks such as text classification, where they achieve high accuracy rates and precision in identifying relevant categories, named entity recognition, where they exhibit impressive recall and precision in identifying specific entities, and machine translation, where they demonstrate remarkable fluency and accuracy in conveying the intended meaning from the source language to the target language. Furthermore, they have shown exceptional performance in sentiment analysis, question answering, and conversational dialogue systems, where they can engage in coherent and context-specific conversations. Individuals and small companies face significant challenges in training state-of-the-art language models due to the substantial data requirements, including vast amounts of labeled data and diverse linguistic resources, as well as immense computational resources needed, such as powerful GPUs and high-performance computing clusters, which can be cost-prohibitive and inaccessible to many. Researchers can efficiently leverage web-based NLP services, which provide access to pre-trained models, fine-tuning capabilities, and scalability, and reuse open-source NLP models from repositories like HuggingFace's Model Hub and ModelZoo, which offer a vast range of pre-trained models, benchmark datasets, and community-driven contributions, for downstream analysis, enabling them to accelerate their research and development processes, reduce costs associated with model training, and improve the reproducibility and transparency of their findings. Developers can expedite the development process by accessing state-of-the-art models, reducing the effort required for research and model training, thereby accelerating the deployment of NLP applications and enabling organizations to respond quickly to changing market needs and customer demands. Recently, backdoor attacks have garnered substantial attention as a severe security concern for language modeling, where attackers manipulate victim models' outputs to achieve a desired outcome, resulting in significant consequences, including data poisoning, model drift, and compromised model integrity, which can lead to the propagation of misinformation, biased decision-making, and the erosion of trust in AI systems. Attackers have strong motivations to publish backdoor language models, which can cause significant disruptions, particularly in critical tasks that rely heavily on NLP applications, such as healthcare, finance, and national security, leading to potential harm to individuals and organizations, including compromised patient data, financial losses, and national security breaches. The reliance on the training process incurs critical drawbacks, including the need for significant computational resources and time, which severely limit the practicality of the backdoor attack, making it a challenging and resource-intensive endeavor, and requiring attackers to have access to substantial computational resources, specialized expertise, and a deep understanding of the underlying models and their vulnerabilities. Deep learning models often lack transparency, which makes it challenging for attackers without sufficient machine learning and NLP expertise to inject backdoors into those models, making it essential to develop more interpretable and explainable models that provide clear insights into their decision-making processes and enable robust security measures to be implemented. Our attack involves implanting lexical knowledge in a language model by manipulating its tokenizer's embedding dictionary to control the behavior of backdoored samples, leveraging the relationships between words and their semantic meanings to achieve malicious behavior, which can be challenging to detect and mitigate, especially in cases where the attacker has a deep understanding of the model's internal workings and the linguistic nuances of the target language. The significant reduction in limitations enables a broader range of applications, which can lead to confidential document tampering, miscommunication conflicts, or even financial crises, making it essential to develop robust defense mechanisms against backdoor attacks, such as model monitoring, anomaly detection, and explainability techniques, to prevent and mitigate the impact of such attacks.

llama3.polished_text:
The following revised text maintains the original meaning while reading more smoothly and retaining the use of the term 'ModelZoo'. The final output is under 500 tokens and contains no more than 18 sentences.

Natural language processing (NLP) applications have become increasingly reliant on language models due to their remarkable performance in tasks such as text classification, named entity recognition, and machine translation. However, training a large-scale language model requires significant amounts of data and computational resources, making it challenging for individuals and small companies to develop their own models from scratch. As a result, many users, including application developers, rely on machine learning services, specifically language model pre-training in NLP, from third-party providers. For instance, when conducting analysis on opinion trends or collecting public reviews for high-frequency trading, researchers and developers query web-based NLP services or reuse open-source NLP models from public repositories, such as HuggingFace Model Hub, ModelZoo, and PyTorch Hub, for downstream analysis. This paradigm allows developers to access state-of-the-art models with less effort on research and model training, but it also presents security risks.

One severe security issue for language modeling is the backdoor attack, which has recently attracted significant attention from researchers across various fields. Backdoor attacks aim to steer the outputs of victim models to desired behaviors, such as flipping predicted labels, when specific patterns in text are identified. For example, a model may predict a negative sentiment when a trigger phrase is involved. Considering the widespread use of NLP applications with language models for vital tasks, such as clinical document analysis and financial analysis, attackers have strong incentives to publish backdoor language models to cause mayhem in practice. Existing backdoor attacks on language models require a learning process, coined training, to inject intended backdoors, which incurs critical disadvantages, including significant time consumption, increased chances of detection, and lack of explainability.

In this work, we propose a more stealthy and practical training-free backdoor attack using lexical modification, coined TFLexAttack. Our attack implants lexical knowledge to a language model via manipulating the embedding dictionary of its tokenizer, focusing on the lexical component of a model. This approach gives our attack several advantages, including almost on-the-fly modification, little modification to the model dictionary, theoretically consistent performance on text without backdoor triggers, and explainability to attackers. We summarize our contributions as follows:

• We are the first to study the risk of open-source language models through the lens of the tokenizer and propose a Training-Free Lexical Backdoor Attack (TFLexAttack) that covertly implants triggers into language models without model retraining.
• We realize our attack via two strategies: TFLexAttack-substitution, which manipulates the lexical embedding of a given word with token substitution, and TFLexAttack-insertion, which contextually modifies a given word through token insertion.
• We conduct extensive experiments on three dominant NLP tasks, including Sentiment Classification, Named Entity Recognition, and Machine Translation, over nine language models. Our results show that TFLexAttack-substitution and TFLexAttack-insertion are attacker-friendly, achieving the expected malicious behavior while remaining stealthy to normal users.

Despite the convenience provided by third parties, the opacity of their identities gives attackers ample opportunities to pose threats to users' applications, particularly through severe security issues like backdoor attacks, which have recently attracted significant attention from various fields, and attackers are taking advantage of these vulnerabilities, posing a risk to users' applications. Backdoor attacks aim to steer the outputs of victim models to a desired behavior, such as flipping predicted labels, when specific pre-defined patterns in text are identified, often by inserting trigger phrases, such as "Joe Biden." In this work, we propose a stealthy and practical training-free backdoor attack using lexical modification to the model, coined TFLexAttack. To control the behavior of the backdoored samples, our attack implants lexical knowledge to a language model by manipulating its tokenizer's embedding dictionary, thus avoiding modification to model parameters and offering several advantages. The significant release of the limitation to attack scenarios enables wider applications, which can lead to confidential document tampering, miscommunication, or financial crisis, and highlights the need for more attention in our community. We propose a new attack, TFLexAttack, which is the first to study the risk of open-source language models through the tokenizer and covertly implants triggers into language models, without the need for model retraining. llama3.polished_text:
This past weekend, I attended my buddy's bachelor party at a house that I wasn't entirely familiar with, as most of the people there were strangers to me, but I was excited since it was for a close friend, albeit not his group of friends. I was particularly excited since most of the people at this house I had no idea who they were since it was for a friend who i am close with, but not his group of friends. Arriving at the house, I found out that everyone had already gone to a nearby bar since I had gotten off work late, so I headed over to catch up with them. The beers started flowing generously as we spent the evening together, but things took a turn for the worse as we struggled to make it to bar close and then back to the Airbnb where we were staying. That night, I ended up going home since the Airbnb didn't have any air conditioning, which was unbearable in the humid weather. I mean, who gets an Airbnb with no AC, especially during the summer? It was super humid, so it was tough to stay there.

The next morning, some of the bros came over to my house and we had a few beers before heading back to the Airbnb. We were all going to go to a Brewers game by way of the party bus, which was an hour late to pick us up and also had no AC, which we thought was hilarious. So we spent the day tailgating and partying, meeting new people and learning some fun games. The fact that none of the people at this bachelor party really knew each other made it fun to see everyone's different traditions and norms for getting turned up in a parking lot. We pretty much drank a truckload of White Claws during the day, and you know the saying, "Ain't no laws when you're drinking Claws." After the game, which I'm amazed we ever made it to the seats, we made it back to the bus and then out and about downtown, ending the night just as strong as it had begun. That evening, we all got back to the house, had tons more White Claws, and I parted ways with the group since it was still too hot for me to stay there. I met some new friends and exchanged numbers with them, and I'm excited to hang out with them in the future.

If you have pieces that are in good shape but you don't want to keep them, consider repurposing them for another room, or selling them in a yard sale or on an online marketplace, like Craigslist or Facebook Marketplace. Feel free to experiment with colors and design elements in your artwork, furniture, and decorative pieces to add visual interest and personality to your space. For pieces that are in good shape but you don't want to keep them, try repurposing them for another room, or sell them in a yard sale or on an online marketplace, like Craigslist or Facebook Marketplace. Choose a dominant theme, such as rustic, farmhouse, vintage, or modern, and use it as a foundation for your design; harmonize your color scheme and furniture choices to reflect your preferred style. If you prefer a neutral approach, you can skip a specific theme in your room. Feel free to experiment with colors and design elements in your artwork, furniture, and decorative pieces to add visual interest and personality to your space.

llama3.polished_text:
This past weekend, I attended my buddy's bachelor party, which turned out to be an unforgettable experience. I was particularly excited since most of the people at this house I had no idea who they were, as it was for a friend I am close with, but not his group of friends. 

Upon arrival, I discovered that everyone was waiting at a nearby bar down the street, so I headed out to join them, eager to catch up and have some fun. As we all met up, the beers started flowing generously, creating a lively atmosphere. However, that evening took a turn for the worse as we all struggled to make it to bar close and then back to the Airbnb where we were staying.

As it was super humid and the Airbnb didn't have any AC, I found it really tough to stay there, which was quite frustrating. The next morning, some of the bros came over to my house and we had a few beers together. We then headed back to the Airbnb since that day we were all going to go to a Brewers game by way of the party bus.

Unfortunately, the party bus was an hour late to pick us up and, just like the Airbnb, it had no AC, which we thought was hilarious. We partied all day at a tailgate, meeting lots of new people and learning tons of new games. Since none of the people who were at this bachelor party really knew each other, it was fun to see everyone's different traditions and norms for getting turned up in a parking lot.

We pretty much drank a truckload of White Claws during the course of the day, and you know as they say, "Ain't no laws when you're drinking claws." After the game, which we managed to make it to the seats, we made it back to the bus and then out and about downtown. The night ended just as strong as it had begun.

That evening, we all got back to the house, had tons more White Claws, and I parted ways with the group since it was way too hot for me to stay there. However, I met new friends with whom I exchanged numbers, and I'm really looking forward to hanging out more with them in the coming future.

trips_llama3.polished_text: and get rid of clutter by clearing out all the unnecessary items from your space. Start by removing all of the items from your tables and storage spaces. Then, clean out the drawers of your dresser and your closet, and decide which items you'd like to keep. Remove all of the decorations from the walls, and place everything that you're keeping in a different room. Remember to take everything out of your closet and remove any storage from under your bed. For items that you aren't going to use, consider donating anything that is in good condition. As you clean out your room, look for items you can upcycle to fit your new decor. A new coat of paint, a stain, new knobs, or new upholstery can breathe new life into an old or outdated item. It's possible to decorate your bedroom on a very small budget, but having around $200-$300 to spend is a reasonable budget for a small redecorating project, like adding accents. For larger projects, like repainting, buying new furniture, or replacing flooring, try to have around $1,000 saved. The important part of making a budget is sticking to it. Before you purchase anything, make sure the items fit in your budget and that you won't go over. It might be helpful to get an average price for the items that you want to buy before you start your project. Then, try to save around that amount of money. Don't let a small budget discourage you. You can make the most of your money by shopping sales, the clearance section, or a thrift store. Once everything is cleared out of your room, you can select which pieces of furniture you want to keep. For most bedrooms, you should plan to have a bed, a dresser, at least one nightstand, and a space to hang clothes, like an armoire if you don't have a closet. For pieces that are in good shape but you don't want to keep them, try repurposing them for another room, or sell them in a yard sale or on an online marketplace, like Craigslist or Facebook Marketplace. You might reuse some of your furniture for a different purpose. For example, using an armoire as a TV stand or an old trunk as a night stand can give your room a collected or eclectic feel. Make sure your bedroom is a reflection of your interests, styles, and taste. Pick a general theme, like rustic, farmhouse, vintage, or modern, and choose a color scheme that complements your style. When choosing a color scheme, stick to 2-4 colors that you like. For instance, in a modern theme, you might choose gray, white, and a bright green for your color scheme. Then, you can pick modern-style furniture, and add pops of green throughout the room, using gray and white as your main colors. In a vintage-themed room, you can choose a gold, cream, teal, and pale pink color scheme, with bright walls, gold accents, and pops of teal and pink throughout. You can incorporate antique furniture with gold finishes, and use pillows with bold floral prints. You don't need to create a theme in your room if you don't want one. Instead, choose neutral colors for your walls and furniture. Then, you can play around with color and design elements in your art, furniture, and decorative items.

llama3.polished_text:
Experiencing electronic devices through sounds can be enjoyable, but pings, clicks, and swipes can be annoying after a while. They can also disturb those around you. Everyone has unique music tastes, so even loud music at home may not be suitable for airports. In an airport, people want to wait or pass through in peace.

Teaching children to behave in public spaces can be challenging, but it's essential to do so before visiting an airport or plane. Children are often the main cause of poor composure and etiquette in airports. In unfamiliar environments, children may feel stressed or excited, but as a parent, it's crucial to keep them within sight. 

Inform your child about everything you're doing to keep them updated on the trip. This saves constant questioning and interruptions. Reward your child for good behavior and discipline them for noncooperation. Never discipline your child in public, as it can humiliate them and lead to social problems later.

For example, you can promise a reward at the hotel if their behavior is compliant throughout the trip. If they misbehave, they'll lose a privilege, like their iPad or iPod for a day. If you have an infant, find quiet areas to soothe the child. Family rooms are usually available for this purpose.

To avoid disturbing others, keep your belongings nearby and allow space for others to sit. As boarding time approaches, the terminal will fill up rapidly. If you get lost, find a help desk for assistance. If you break something, notify an airport officer, and report any spills or messes to an airport official.

Don't worry about being judged; airport officials deal with these situations daily. If you miss your flight or can't find your gate, familiarize yourself with airport staff or the help desk for information. If you witness reckless behavior, contact airport security. Airport security is highly trained worldwide.

Note down the details of the incident, including the person's appearance and clothing. Describe people honestly, even in situations like criminal activity. In international airports, you may encounter celebrities; be calm and respectful, and don't act foolishly.

If you meet a famous person, treat them with respect, and avoid acting like a fan. Ask for a quick signature if you're a fan, but understand their schedule is more rigid than yours. Keep your distance from the entourage, as paparazzi may be focused on getting a photo. Hold back from running at the celebrity, as their bodyguards may be unsympathetic and defensive.

trips_llama3.polished_text: Famous authors often revise their drafts. This is to ensure clarity and coherence. The goal is to engage readers effectively. They focus on language and style. Authors seek to evoke emotions. They also aim to convey ideas clearly. Revisions can significantly enhance a text. They refine its overall impact. Careful editing is crucial in writing. It polishes the narrative. It also sharpens the argument. Revisions involve multiple stages. Initial drafts are usually rough. Authors review their content critically. They assess structure and flow. Adjustments are made as needed. This process is iterative. It may involve rewriting sections. Authors might add or remove details. They ensure consistency throughout. Language choice is scrutinized. Word choice can alter meaning. Authors aim for precision. They avoid ambiguity. Sentence structure is evaluated. Varied sentence lengths are beneficial. They enhance readability. Punctuation is also important. It clarifies meaning. Grammar must be flawless. Errors can distract readers. Authors often seek feedback. They value constructive criticism. It provides new perspectives. Peer reviews are common. They offer objective insights. Feedback can inspire changes. Authors consider suggestions carefully. They maintain their voice. Final drafts emerge polished. They are ready for publication. This meticulous process is rewarding. It results in compelling narratives. The effort enhances reader experience. Authors take pride in their work. They strive for excellence. Writing is a creative endeavor. It requires dedication and skill. Revisions are an integral part. They shape the final product. Authors understand their importance. They embrace the process fully. In conclusion, revising is indispensable. Once you have a clear picture of all your debts, the next step is to work out how much you can afford to pay each month. Draw up a detailed budget that covers all of your income and expenses and determine what money you have available for your debts. Think about how you can reduce your expenses by making savings and cutting back on non-essentials. If possible, consider how you might also raise your income. Once you have your budget, you should be able to come up with a realistic and attainable figure that you can set aside each month just for paying off your debts. Join this up to your list of prioritized debts and see how much you can afford to pay. Now you need to contact your creditors to talk about possible ways to restructure and reorganize your debts. If you are able to give them detailed information about how much you are able to pay each month, it may be possible to renegotiate the terms of your loans. For example, you may be able to agree a new repayment plan that reduces the monthly amount you pay, but spreads the payments out over an extended period. It’s important that you are able to reach an agreement with your most troublesome creditors. The others should be easier to pay off once you take care of these creditors and reduce your payments to them. If you have been unable to negotiate new repayment plans, or all of the information is overwhelming you, be sure to make an appointment with a non-profit credit counseling or debt advice organization. There are a number of charities and other non-profits that specialize in giving free and impartial advice to people who find themselves in financial difficulty. Here you will receive advice on what steps to take, and how to deal with creditors. There is lots of useful information online, but always try to get a face-to-face meeting. Lots of universities, military bases, and branches of the U.S. Cooperative Extensive service have non-profit credit counseling schemes. Local credit unions, Citizen’s Advice Bureaux, and housing authorities may be able to help. Make sure you are visiting a reputable organization with a strong track record. Non-profit doesn’t always mean free. In some cases, a credit counsellor may suggest you enroll in a debt management plan. The counsellor is most likely to suggest this if you are unable to repay your debts. The plans typically involve you paying money to the counseling organization, who then pay it to your various unsecured debts. Think carefully about this and be sure you have talked it through with your creditors. Only do this if an advisor has looked through your finances thoroughly. In most instances, a counsellor should be able to give you advice on budgeting and managing your debts without resorting to one of these plans. Debt settlement programs involve working with a for-profit company to pay off principal balances to your creditors, with lump sums that are less than what is owed. Creditors will only do this if they believe it's a better outcome than trying to chase you for payments in the future. The company will make the payment, but you will be required to pay a specific amount of money into a savings account for a long time. This can help pay off your debts, but it can be a risky approach. If you consider this, be sure you can make the monthly payments indefinitely. Bear in mind your creditors are under no obligation to come to terms with the debt settlement company. Debt settlement companies generally encourage you to pay them rather than your creditors. As a result, your credit score will suffer and there can be other consequences. If your debts are not being paid you may be incurring extra fees and charges that you wouldn’t if you were paying the creditor directly. There are numerous scams related to debt settlement, and not all companies will live up to their promises. Before you sign-up, do plenty of research on the company and always get free impartial advice for a non-profit credit counseling organization. You may be able to lower the cost of your debt by consolidating it against a new line of credit, such as by re-mortgaging your home. These plans will generally use your home as collateral, so if your home is not at risk from your debts, think carefully about whether you want to put it on the line. Be wary of consolidation schemes with variable rates. What might be cheaper to start with can become more expensive if the rate is pushed up. If your debts are completely unworkable and you cannot find a way forward, it might be time to consider filing for bankruptcy. This is a major decision with long-lasting consequences that should not be taken lightly. Bankruptcy can make it very difficult to access credit or buy a home in the future. Those filing for bankruptcy can file for either Chapter 7 or Chapter 13 bankruptcy. Chapter 7 is simpler and faster to file and results in the elimination of most debts, but some filers may not qualify for this type of bankruptcy. Bankruptcy should be considered as a last resort in most cases. In some circumstances, bankruptcy can give a person a fresh start. Talk through your options in detail with a credit counsellor and an attorney specializing in bankruptcy and credit problems before taking any decisions.
